books.title: Bring the House Down
books.author: Charlotte Runcie
books.review: Unputdownable! I was rapt! More thoughtful review to come. -- "Bring Down The House," is narrated by Sophie, a junior arts critic for a large British newspaper. However, the book is about Alex, the head theater critic. He writes scathing one star reviews and very rarely gives out 5 star reviews. Sophie and Alex are both covering a theater festival in Edinburgh that is 3 weeks long. They are staying together throughout the festival. Early on, Alex attends a one woman show on climate change, that he gives 1 star. As soon as he submits his article for publication the next day, he sees the exact woman from the show at the same bar as him. They end up sleeping together that night. In the morning, she reads his scathing review of her show and is furious. She then changes her show to tell this story with a live audience. Many of Alex's past lovers come out of the woodwork to share how he mistreated them too. Alex gets cancelled. I thought the whole book was engrossing. I felt like I was there with them at the festival. The ending was kind of a mess (the woman from the show almost kills everyone at her final show by accidentally setting the theater on fire and Sophie almost dies) but to me, there were many points that struck me. 1. Sophie is a new mom, like me. She has to leave her only son, Arlo, with her husband, who she has grown distant from since having Arlo. This wasn't a major plot point but it was nice to see someone else struggling in the new motherhood trenches. Her in-laws were incredibly rude and unhelpful to her, an experience I relate to deeply. Sophie's own mother has recently died of cancer and this is a major part of the book. However, as a Goodreads reviewer I respect, Jessica Woodbury, has pointed out. This grief narrative just didn't quite work and felt disjointed from the crux of the book (Alex's cancellation). 2. Is it fair to critique art? I felt inspired and invigorated by Alex. I also love to critique things - specifically books. I related to the sentiment that books are either 1 star or 5 stars, and any score in between is ambivalence on the critic's end. One of my biggest gripes is not being able to find people who have the same reading taste as me. I never know what to read next. Goodreads is how I get most of my recs. I read books, then read the reviews and follow reviewers who I seem to have similar taste to. So I have to scroll through their "read" list when the user experience on GR is so abysmal. If I click on a review of one of the books they've read and try to go back to where I was in their "read" list, it spits me back to the top of the list, this is very frustrating and tedious. It doesn't help that the "books you might enjoy since you just read this book" feature on GR is an absolute train wreck. This got me thinking about how Julia Cameron (author of "The Artist's Way") says that critics are blocked artists. Therefore, on some level, Alex must want to be an actor or affiliated with theater production, instead of critiquing it. I think this is true. I love to point out all the flaws of a novel, but I have never written a novel! I desperately want to be a published author but my actions don't align with my words! This also makes me think of what Brene Brown says (I think it's an FDR quote? nope is Teddy Rosevelt) about being in the ring. If you're not in the ring, you don't get to criticize me. Get in the arena yourself, then you can talk. You can't just sit on the sidelines and point out the flaws of others. In other words, it is an incredibly vulnerable act to put your art out into the world. Anyone can be a critic, not everyone can be an artist. 3. I suppose this should be point number 1 but the book centers on #MeToo and ethical boundaries. Alex seems like a real POS but did he do anything ILLEGAL? No. Nonconsensual? No. But what he did was still...ick. And it turns out he's ick to every woman he's ever been with. What a joy! I know many men like this. Ultimately I was most mad at Sophie for being so spineless around him. She ultimately wanted to hook up with him even though she had a first hand account of all of his horribleness. Also, did they even hook up? Sophie ends up telling her husband that they did but they like barely kissed and then stopped. I don't even think this constitutes cheating but I guess that makes me immoral? Ultimately when I enjoy a book, I find it really hard to articulate why! Maybe that means I am a bad writer or maybe that means that art is hard to simply wrap up into a flattened rating. This reminds me of C. Thi Nguyen's work about how we quantify and add metrics to basic human experiences (sleeping, eating, running, etc) and this takes something three dimensional and truncates it into something easily digestible when that's not how human life works. Humans are messy. Art is messy. It can't be summed up in a matter of stars. And everyone has different tastes. One man can't decide what is "good" and what is "bad."

books.title: Exalted
books.author: Anna Dorn
books.review: I've been in an Anna dorn rabbit hole since I read vagablonde. This was the most superficial of the bunch but it was still quite fun!

books.title: Discontent
books.author: Beatriz Serrano
books.review: Lol the ending was ridiculous. I'm currently about to interview for jobs after a 3 year break and this made me NOT WANT TO AT ALL.

books.title: Bad Lawyer: A Memoir of Law and Disorder
books.author: Anna Dorn
books.review: As a fellow cal bear (I went for undergrad) who always thought I'd end up a lawyer, I related to a lot of this. I read the acknowledgments of her first novel and mistook "thanks mom for always listening to my dumb ideas" as "thanks for always supporting me" but it turns out her mom is kind of b who wants her to be someone else too! Always nice to feel less alone in this way. I partly wished I had gone to law school bc I am such a striver with low self worth and it sounds right up my alley. Alas I went into finance instead and now I am an unemployed aspiring writer lol... she mentions her privilege but I don't really get how people go to law school on someone else's dime and don't feel wracked w guilt. She didn't seem grateful for any of her privilege. I don't know. I found a lot of it boring? I like her novels more.

books.title: Perfume & Pain
books.author: Anna Dorn
books.review: Sadly I didn't like this one as much as "vagablonde" but I seem to be an outlier. Perhaps bc I read them back to back and they had a lot of similarities? I still am very much into Anna dorn and I think I'll read her memoir on her experience as a lawyer next.

books.title: Vagablonde
books.author: Anna Dorn
books.review: Loved it! Sad it's over. I was very stressed for the cats but I perservered. Prue is me and I am Prue (but I am sober). I was annoyed reading in the acknowledgements that the author's mother is actually her #1 fan because I related so much to Prue's cold mom who is never proud of her. Oh well. Maybe one day I'll get over my mommy issues...This was a fun romp and now I will read her other book "perfume & pain."

books.title: Ghosts
books.author: Dolly Alderton
books.review: This book was basically a poor rip off of "nobody tells you this." Dragged on and then it just...ended? I do not get the dolly hype. I've tried multiple books of hers! Oh well.

books.title: The Dream Hotel
books.author: Laila Lalami
books.review: This was disturbing because it does not feel dystopian enough. Too real. Spoilers to come - she gets freed because Julie is sloppy and signs her real name?? COME ON. and they never show Julie's perspective again? So cheap. So lazy! This was not a page turner but I also wanted to keep going. The "read with jenna" sticker is an automatic turn off but I was still intrigued and would not have guessed this would be a pick of a today show host. Anyway this made me really triggered bc I have a young child and the fact that she was separated from her babies over nothing is enough to set me over the edge. I would probably have lost the will to live and taken my own life if I had been Sara. The ending was just way too neat.

books.title: What Kind of Paradise
books.author: Janelle Brown
books.review: I do not get the hype. Tedious and boring. Reads like YA.

books.title: The Compound
books.author: Aisling Rawle
books.review: Couldn't put it down!! It was like the craziest bad reality show. I ate it up!

books.title: Audition
books.author: Katie Kitamura
books.review: I need a full analysis of what this was!!

books.title: Sea of Tranquility
books.author: Emily St. John Mandel
books.review: Not sure what do make of this. I could definitely tell this was the author of station 11. Why does she do dystopia so well? It's unnerving. I enjoyed it and finished in one sitting (was surprised it was so short) but I'm not really sure what the point was? Maybe I'm an idiot?

books.title: We Play Ourselves
books.author: Jen Silverman
books.review: This was really weird but had brief moments where I wanted to underline things but I was listening to it as an audiobook. The desire for success is deep in me and I am 33 like Cass and feeling like a failure so there was a lot I related to even though a lot of it was rather eccentric. The end was kind of blah.

books.title: The Tell: A Memoir
books.author: Amy Griffin
books.review: okay so this book took me on a wild ride. at first, i was fully invested. i cared deeply about her story and wanted to find out the "secret." once it was revealed, i totally believed her (and I still do). I am having my own "being failed by the justice system/loophole riddled experience." so her quest for justice, i felt it deeply. one of my (many) toxic traits is that when i'm reading/watching something, i am so impatient that i must look up the subject even before i've finished the book/movie. so i look amy up. she's very thin, blonde and pretty. this in itself is not a crime, obviously. but then i realize the john she's married to is a billionaire hedge fund dude. all the photos of her on the internet are with oprah, gwenyth paltrow, reese witherspoon, etc. and a bunch of photos of her and her husband at the met gala - why?? this book is an oprah's book club selection but i had never heard of it until i read lena dunham's substack and a guest writer said she was reading it. then after the google images i saw what an intense pr machine was backing this book. then the parts that didn't work for me bubble to the surface. when she said she wants to go back to work once her kids are in school after being a full time stay at home mom (who doesn't cook) and she just decides i'll be a venture capitalist and fund women owned companies! one does not simply go from stay at home mom to VC overnight...you have to have a billionaire husband....that felt like an important disclosure to me?? this is key context into why she was able to wallow for months/years and everything in her life kept going without a hitch. i googled john griffin and the first article i found was about how he flew his private jet to new zealand before corona was announced as an emergency situation. yuck. so i started reading the goodreads reviews before i finished the book (i hate when I do this!) and i soured on her completely. people pointed out how self absorbed she was and i couldn't unsee this. i think her points about wanting to be "perfect" ring true for many eldest daughters (myself included). i always want to make myself small (physically and emotionally) and to not take up space. i look back on so many moments of my life with boys/men in intimate settings and wish i had just said NO! but i didn't feel like i had any agency at the time. i was so used to overriding my bodily instincts to please others. so i appreciated her telling her story in that regard. but i do agree that i wish there was more internal reflection. she constantly says shes "done the work" but i still don't think she knows what this means. this is different for everyone but i think she is still in the early innings. aka when you shouldn't be writing a memoir and having oprah tout its glory. others pointed out that amy was shocked that so many women have experienced sexual abuse. like WHAT. how could she be so naive/ignorant?? i don't believe it for a second. it just seems like her life was pleasantville in b&w and now she's seeing the slightest bit of color. she seems like she was a sad person before. i am happy she has gone to therapy but i think there's still so much for her to learn before she uses her platform this way. it is interesting the way i criticize her more deeply for being a wealthy, pretty, white woman. i just expect her to do more with her privelige. like others on goodreads, i wish she had used her power for better. this just all feels pretty self indulgent. which i guess tracks because she never admitting a single thing in her book that made her look bad. it was effusive in its self praise - i am the nicest, and the best. except i didn't win homecoming queen once. that sucked. lol. i relate to her wanting to tie up the story in a bow and recognizing that life just doesn't turn out that way. i also relate to feeling like you need to prove yourself to your parents. i related so much to that. i am constantly trying to untangle myself from the mess that is me trying to please my parents. but i know these wounds/beliefs run deep. tldr - mixed feelings on this book. everyone is inherently an unreliable narrator. not that i don't believe this happened to her. i do. it's just the way she paints herself as this saint that didn't sit right with me. everyone is multi-faceted. i have a hard time believing she was so...bland. i guess the patriarchy runs deep and if you marry a billionaire all you focus on is being "perfect." im sure reese will make this into a hulu show soon but i think there are so many other books that would be better. read "what my bones know" or "know my name" if you want to read about women truly confronting their trauma with more authenticity.

books.title: The God of the Woods
books.author: Liz Moore
books.review: I did not like the ending but I didn't see it coming so that's something. I was gripped. I do not care for books that switch between years and narrators but this was not as annoying as it usually is.

books.title: Careless People: A Cautionary Tale of Power, Greed, and Lost Idealism
books.author: Sarah Wynn-Williams
books.review: Am I an idiot? I ATE "Lean In" up when I graduated college in 2014. I think I received 4 different copies of that book for graduation. I was going to lean in so hard!! The goal was to be like sheryl! Years later, I crashed and burned and realized I am not sheryl. I don't think it's fair to blame my 22 year old self for not being more of a critical thinker but damn, it seems so clear now that sheryl's suggestions are insanely toxic and ignore systemic issues. maybe I'm just naive and easy to convince (just like my 22 year old self) but I LOVED this memoir. I was GRIPPED the entire time. I love toxic corporate tell alls and this one was so well written. she is clearly such a badass (the shark attack in the beginning SHOOK me). I kept thinking "damn, did she not have to sign an nda??" but AI tells me that she did: "Multiple sources confirm that Wynn-Williams signed a non-disparagement agreement as part of her severance package upon her departure from Meta. This agreement falls under the broader category of NDAs (non-disclosure agreements) and specifically prohibits making "disparaging, critical, or otherwise harmful" remarks about the company. Meta initiated arbitration proceedings against Wynn-Williams immediately after the release of her book, arguing that her memoir violated this agreement. The arbitrator issued an emergency order barring her from promoting or discussing her book and from making any critical statements about Meta. Reports indicate that Wynn-Williams was required to sign this agreement in order to receive financial compensation upon leaving the company." Interesting...so she's allowed to publish but not promote...weird but I'm here for it. She does not disappoint with the tea! What a shit show at the fuck factory. I deleted my FB account in 2018 after the Cambridge analytica scandal but reactivated it in 2021 to use marketplace. I hate that I still have a FB account. at least I deleted insta in 2021. I try to limit my interactions with the algorithm but even substack is feeling fraught these days. I'm sure she's not the saint that she paints herself as...and the whole "I can do more change on the inside" schtick is (to me) clearly a coverup to feel better about working at a bad place (and knowing you are by association, bad too but you want that $$$). I am going through my own whistleblowing disaster so this book was very timely for me. what a sad world we live in...ugh I will write more on that eventually... My only gripe is the title "careless people" sounds to much like "careless whisper." another reviewer said "swimming with sharks" was right there and yes, it would have been so much better if that were the title! 100% recommend you read this ASAP! I need to know what she's up to now!

books.title: Crush
books.author: Ada Calhoun
books.review: This was a hate read. Reminded me of Leslie Jamison's "splinters" - the writing is good but the content is such a drag. The writers are so self obsessed. The reader never gets rewarded for reading. There's no growth. I don't know why I muscled through it. I'm pretty bored. Help I don't know how to pick books to read!!

books.title: The Wedding People
books.author: Alison Espach
books.review: This was shallow but fun

books.title: Rules of Civility
books.author: Amor Towles
books.review: What a delight! Got a little bored in the middle but it was worth finishing! I especially enjoyed the epilogue.

books.title: Rental House
books.author: Weike Wang
books.review: This was not fun at all to read. The author frequently writes about interracial marriage, which she does well, but this one was a slog.

books.title: Intermezzo
books.author: Sally Rooney
books.review: I feel like I'm taking crazy pills!! How could this have such a high average rating??? As someone else said "Perhaps she's so popular because she's managed to make soft-porn romance intellectually respectable." This book was absolute trash. I loved conversations with friends, watched the tv series of normal people and loved it, felt meh when I read the book (it was just like the show which I guess is good?), and was not impressed with beautiful world. But this...this was HORRIBLE. Dragged on and on. So boring. Can't even believe I powered through. Rooney loves damaged/flat/victim women (usually so physically brutalized that they are disabled somehow) - what is that about?

books.title: All Fours
books.author: Miranda July
books.review: Lots of gratuitous sex but otherwise intriguing.

books.title: Long Island Compromise
books.author: Taffy Brodesser-Akner
books.review: I loved her first book but HATED this one.

books.title: Memory Piece
books.author: Lisa Ko
books.review: This book sucked. Started okay but became unbearable.

books.title: Real Americans
books.author: Rachel Khong
books.review: Really boring.

books.title: Private Equity: A Memoir
books.author: Carrie Sun
books.review: Couldn't put it down! Kind of a mix of the book "what my bones know" (lots of undiagnosed c-ptsd) and the shows "industry" (without the sex) and "billions" I didn't realize this was a memoir for the first chunk of it - it reads like a novel! I definitely agree with other reviews, in that I don't buy that Sun didn't know what she was getting herself into. I question her rationale. She graduates from MIT, works in finance (for Fidelity) doing quant work, starts getting her MBA at Wharton, then drops out. She tells herself she wants a day job to support her writing but then decides to work as an EA for the most intense hedge fund ever. If she was straight out of college...maybe I could see her naivete but at age 29 after working in the industry and deciding not to get an MBA - she clearly knew what she was getting herself into. She knew she wouldn't be doing any writing - this wouldn't be just a "day job" to support her writing (she does no writing in the 2+ years at the fund). It also drove me nuts that she was an assistant when she was clearly capable of being an analyst or PM. WHY?? Why debase yourself like that? I will never understand. Oh also when she got back together with her ex - WHY CARRIE, WHY? Clearly I'm attracted to books about toxic corporate culture right now ("exit interview" was about how terrible working at Amazon is). I wonder why that is. I lived it so I really don't need to read more about it. I must feel like I have to validate my decision to drop out of the rat race...

books.title: Exit Interview: The Life and Death of My Ambitious Career
books.author: Kristi Coulter
books.review: Sooo depressing but well written and engaging. Makes me never want to return to the hell hole which is the corporate world!!

books.title: The Adult
books.author: Bronwyn Fischer
books.review: Not good. Shallow.

books.title: The Guest
books.author: Emma Cline
books.review: Very stressful. I need to know what happens!! Most relatable part of the book: "Simon maintained such psychotic discipline because he seemed to believe even the smallest lapse in vigilance would result in catastrophe. And probably he was right. Occasionally the control dropped: Simon took a jar of peanut butter to the couch, eating with fastidious care until it was empty, the spoon licked clean by his surprisingly pink tongue. He gazed sadly into the scraped jar, as if oftended by the sight."

books.title: Mexican Gothic
books.author: Silvia Moreno-Garcia
books.review: I did not enjoy this book one bit. For some reason at first I thought this was an Isabel Allende book. Lol so wrong. Anne Helen Petersen said she liked this book on the podcast "what should I read next?" Very disappointing. It was so boring. I kept waiting for a twist. Also the sexual scenes were very non consensual and made me deeply uncomfortable. I'm tired of the "evil mushroom" ploy (like hbo show "the last of us"). It's lazy.

books.title: More: A Memoir of Open Marriage
books.author: Molly Roden Winter
books.review: This was kind of a blend of two other memoirs - splinters (Leslie Jamison) and group (Christie Tate). The author is brave and puts A LOT out there. I'm shocked that her husband and mother agreed to be included! It makes me deeply disturbed to know that she has teenage sons that can read this. I find the idea of monogamy forever stifling but I am much too jealous to ever share my partner with anyone. So I agree to long term comfort over short term excitement. I know that being wanted by others is exciting when it's new but will fade. I'm not convinced the author likes her life. I think she would much rather have a closed marriage but knows that her husband wants it to remain open. I feel sad for her because of this. It's clear that she values herself based on men wanting her. And the fact that she skipped a bunch of grades and entered college feeling behind has left a lasting impact on her love life. So interesting the way her life mirrors her mother's. This is frightening when I consider aspects of my mother that I dislike but employ (not sex stuff). I found parts to be really boring but ultimately I finished. Does her husband come from money or is making sounds for movies really that lucrative!? I was so bothered by her lack of acknowledgment of her privilege but at the same time, what did I expect her to say? "Hey everyone, we are loaded and I never worry about what anything costs?" I'd like to read a memoir that tackles the subject of open marriage written by someone more secure.

books.title: Splinters
books.author: Leslie Jamison
books.review: This was a slog to get through. She is an excellent writer but I strongly dislike her as a person. She gets married after 6 months and is in couples therapy after another 6 months and then thinks it's a good idea to have a baby. Then she is surprised when that doesn't fix anything. I also hate when mothers are martyrs and she is the ultimate. She doesn't let her husband do anything to help with childcare but she complains the whole time that she's doing it alone. Also there was no mention of the fact that her ex already had a daughter so maybe he wasn't such an inept father and could have handled some of the responsibilities. Ugh this was a hate read. She has no perspective. Lots of people criticize memoirs that are written in real time because the author hasn't grown from the events yet and this is definitely the case here.

books.title: Tom Lake
books.author: Ann Patchett
books.review: what a BORE!!!

books.title: Goodbye, Vitamin
books.author: Rachel Khong
books.review: Finally a good book in 2024! I only want to read books that authors I like recommend. I googled "what is weike wang reading?" and found this one. I had insomnia and acid reflux and couldn't sleep so I stayed up all night reading this. It's delightful.

books.title: My Husband
books.author: Maud Ventura
books.review: I think I am supposed to find this book witty but I don't.

books.title: Mercury
books.author: Amy Jo Burns
books.review: So soapy. No depth. Similar to "hello beautiful" but worse. I had insomnia so I finished it (a hate read).

books.title: None of This Is True
books.author: Lisa Jewell
books.review: I was very interested until about halfway through... then I got bored. There was no twist because you already knew what was going to happen. The ending wasn't a twist. It was just a lame obfuscation. ALSO after recently watching "may december" I am very tired of directors/authors using stories of adults sleeping with children as entertainment.

books.title: Wellness
books.author: Nathan Hill
books.review: Much too long. So many useless chapters. I have been feeling sickly so I listened to it while dozing. Would not recommend.

books.title: Central Places
books.author: Delia Cai
books.review: Not good. This book was just so...unnecessary. The main character had no depth. It all happened "just like that," devoid of emotion or reflection. The author of "Flawless" (Elise Hu) had this as her 2nd favorite book she read in 2023, so now I can't trust anything she says even though she has a cool blog and I wanted to like her.

books.title: Ripe
books.author: Sarah Rose Etter
books.review: What a depressing book. What was the point?

books.title: Slow Motion: A Memoir of a Life Rescued by Tragedy ‚Äì A Powerful Coming-of-Age Autobiography of Rebellion and Family Survival
books.author: Dani Shapiro
books.review: I struggled to finish this. She was just so tone deaf. Lenny's money really bothered me. I was stressed out by how little she cared about the rules of living. What happened to all of her unpaid bills? Who paid her expenses after she left Lenny? She sold a car he gave her for graduate school? She says this all so casually! Losing her father is traumatic but she was such a cold person. I didn't care about her wellbeing. There was no arc. She didn't learn anything. She just decides to finish school. Bravo? I've tried to read other books by her and couldn't finish. Might not continue trying.

books.title: Hello Beautiful
books.author: Ann Napolitano
books.review: I couldn't put it down! I didn't like the ending though. I also felt like these women were too unforgiving. But I guess I am too...William was a hollow character. The author thanked draymond green in her acknowledgments so that was hugely disappointing.

books.title: The Woman in Me
books.author: Britney Spears
books.review: I had absolutely no intention of reading this book but Spotify just announced that (select) audiobooks are included with premium (they had said they were previously included but were locked/paywalled) and they are pushing Britney's memoir. I'm so glad and sad to have listened to it. It's so terrible what the world did to her. And mainly what her disgusting family did to her. It's a feminist text. Truly eerily similar to how we treated witches, just like Britney says. I do wonder who her ghost writer is because I can't imagine she actually wrote this. But I do know all the stories are real. It helps explain how she behaves now (childlike). I'm devastated for her. I am so happy that she is alive and did not choose to end her life. She is a ray of light and her desire to heal is inspiring. I hope others give this book a chance. I sobbed many times. —- I have not been through anything like the abuse that Britney has suffered but I related so hard to how she was never good enough in her family's eyes. She did EVERYTHING they wanted and it was never enough!! — The part about shaving her head...I felt that SO deeply. You want me to be beautiful? Fuck you.

books.title: Comfort Me with Apples
books.author: Catherynne M. Valente
books.review: This did not work for me. Downgrading to 2 stars from 3.

books.title: Pineapple Street
books.author: Jenny Jackson
books.review: I loved the first half but then Georgiana became absolutely insufferable and the whole white savorism complex was too much.

books.title: Big Swiss
books.author: Jen Beagin
books.review: Not sure how I'm supposed to feel about this book. Reminded me of "the rabbit hutch"

books.title: Yellowface
books.author: R.F. Kuang
books.review: Engrossing! Is this a satire of "American dirt"? Or is that just a dumb white woman's interpretation? Made very weary of traditional publishing! https://youtu.be/JUdFkRdgPDU?si=wmc6zoh9FNiKdSM8 This analysis is

books.title: I Have Some Questions for You
books.author: Rebecca Makkai
books.review: Couldn't put it down!!

books.title: Natural Beauty
books.author: Ling Ling Huang
books.review: I couldn't put it down! It's too close to home... So disturbing to see our culture's obsession with beauty, youth and wellness so bluntly laid out. Makes me want to jettison the spendy tinctures in my bathroom (and I only have a few!) I have always felt deeply flawed for not having a skin care routine. I don't know what a toner is. I put expensive oil on my face and then slather on some cheap alba botanica moisturizer. Am I doing it right? I am embarrassed to admit that I want to emulate Gwyneth. Now I am convinced she's another Ghislaine Maxwell (she's not) who is keeping women down. I read Anne Helen Petersen's substack "culture study" and she recently interviewed Elise Hu, who wrote a book on K-Beauty and aesthetic self-optimization (Flawless: Lessons in Looks and Culture from the K-Beauty Capital) "Our physical appearance gets conflated with the self (even though the concept of the self is so much more nuanced and richer than exteriors), and so a lot of us have internalized the notion of self-care as skincare, or costly treatments. That means there's a thin line between nurturing our bodies in a way that is caring and sensual, and falling into extractive beauty work that benefits powerful interests." Hu goes on to say "we should challenge the system instead of judging the woman" - this one is the hardest part for me!!! I want to shake my friends who get Botox and yell "don't you see you are doing exactly what capitalism wants you to do!?" But it's not their fault, it's the system. And I feel helpless and sad. This also made me think of my mixed feelings about Emily ratikowski. Can a woman demand respect while topless? And profiting off of pandering to the male gaze? I am not sure! Blame the system not the woman... "we need a kinder relationship with ourselves, and by extension, a kinder relationship with each other...I see beauty culture as hustle culture that's reached into our bodies. Hustle culture as applied to disciplining or modifying our bodies isolates us from one another because we end up in competition, looking over our shoulders, and scared to ask for help when we need it. It's a recipe for inequality and marginalization on one end, and anxiety and exhaustion across the system. If we look to nature as a guide, the foundation of a well-lived life and a healthy social ecosystem is actually built on mutual care. So just as we millennials (with enough privilege to do so) need to remap our relationships with work, we can also remap our relationships with aesthetic work. I learned to take a beat and reflect on the ways that we almost automatically adhere to the notion that our worthiness boils down to our looks, and from there, began to untangle that knot. Liberating ourselves from appearance shame is an issue of bodily autonomy —¬†and a matter of social justice —¬†because it informs how we can show up in the world and participate in it." OOF

books.title: The House in the Pines
books.author: Ana Reyes
books.review: What a bore.

books.title: Big Friendship: How We Keep Each Other Close
books.author: Aminatou Sow
books.review: Waffling between two or three stars and decided to be charitable. It was really boring and I never would have finished it if it hadn't been chosen for a book club that I recently joined. The authors simply are not very interesting. I'm amazed this book was published. The idea is solid but the execution is SO underwhelming. Maybe if I had heard of their podcast I would care?

books.title: My Nemesis
books.author: Charmaine Craig
books.review: Loved every minute of it. So much to ponder. -- The main character is flawed and selfish and I worry I am her. Isn't that what books are all about? Seeing ourselves reflected back? This book had so many delicious quotes: "There are those who can't keep sight of themselves and those who can't keep themselves out of their own sight" Can you imagine which one is me and which one is my husband? Why do I have to condemn my husband in the process of condemning myself? "So what does that make us, Camus and me and someone like Charlie? Fantasists like Don Juan? Or only people who need, now and again, to seek refuge from the reality of their lives, the truth of themselves?" I love when a book seeps into my psyche and I feel like I am sharing thoughts with the narrator after I finish the book. A book hasn't grabbed me like this in AGES and I am so pleased. "It is a matter of limits. I am here. Htet is there. There is no question of her rage doing me harm. No question of my using her rage to punish myself. It is her own self-punishment. And she is learning to reconcile herself with what has been, to see that she is worthy of a life without self-harm." This quote is about a victim of human trafficking so I feel insane relating to it but I like the framing. I am worthy of a life without self-harm. Self-harm can take many forms and I see that my internal criticism is self harm (even though it has "helped" me "accomplish" things) The book meditated on a lot of themes that I grapple with - motherhood and femininity. I feel enraged by the choices I have - to be aloof like my mother or all consumed by motherhood. "And what is a parent, finally? The person who puts in the time? Or also the person whose attention—in light of the one known as "child"—isn't overly co-opted by other sights?" It feels so gross to still be so obsessed with my mother's "coolness." I know I am just as cruel (if not more so) as her. Yet we are both precious, sensitive little flowers - although we puff up to cover our insecurities. "I tried to describe the way it feels, to meet your daughter when she's already formed, already harmed by men, and someone capable of looking at you with profound skepticism. If I'd known her before the damage, if I could have prevented it, protected her as a little girl . . ." A man says this of his adopted (trafficked) daughter and it enraged me. Because ultimately every girl will be harmed by men (and women). "Aside from her credulousness, I didn't like the uniformity of her speech, or the symmetry of her hair's layers and highlights, or the shape of her eyebrows and lips, perfected to give her half-frozen face a perpetually sardonic sultriness. Nor did I care for the enhancements peeking out from the deep V of her T-shirt's neckline. Yes, this is a record of meanness and, I admit, perhaps also one of anti-feminism, of how merciless women can be in scrutiny of one another and of how far we may go to prove ourselves enough to be liked." I just had dinner with my in laws and my MIL said she was never competitive with her friends - only in sports. And I said I've always been very competitive with my friends. Then I deflected with what I said with Elise on the podcast about how it manifested in the corporate world because women are made to feel there is only so much space for women in the boardroom. My MIL said because she was a teacher she never felt that. But I call bullshit. I have been competing against women in a non-sport context for as long as I can remember. Every interaction with a woman has come with a comparison for me. Who is prettier? Who is thinner? Smarter? Richer? Better? And it taints my whole way of being. If I am "better" - I can be my whole self because I don't feel like I have "something to prove." But if she is "better," I make it my mission to be liked or to puff up and be just as good and this is insincere and makes them dislike me. And even if I am completely sincere, people will still dislike me and this drives me INSANE! Why do people like [person I went to high school with] go out of their way to de-friend me on Facebook? Am I so evil? The narrator of this book is a contrarian/instigator and I relate to her too much. I know I have been a mean person. The narrator (Tessa) hates the wife of a man she likes because she (Wah) represents the opposite end of the feminine spectrum - so demur, passive, and desperate for male approval. I have felt this wrath towards so many women. "There are times when I can't distinguish my habit of honesty from brutality. The look on Charlie's face then was harrowing, broken and shamed. I suppose if I'd been a more "feminine" woman, someone willing to sacrifice her sense of truth for his masculine pride, I would have immediately found a way to recant my diagnosis or to apologize" !!!! AHHH !!! There are times when I can't distinguish my habit of honesty from brutality...many times...

books.title: My Last Innocent Year
books.author: Daisy Alpert Florin
books.review: Enjoyed the first half more than the second. Captured a very specific time of life. I'm currently attending a college graduation and this is making me nostalgic in a way.

books.title: One True Loves
books.author: Taylor Jenkins Reid
books.review: Read for a book club. Would never have picked this up otherwise. I am very confused why people enjoy this book. First, the castaway story. Come on... Second, her internal turmoil is inane. All the saccharine "profound" musings on love...I can not Some reviews said they liked the ending so I kept waiting for something to happen. Nope nope. So predictable and just...terrible. No more Taylor Jenkins Reid for me. Ever again. I've given her too many chances. She is the Sarah dessen of 30 something's. So trite. Two stars or one?

books.title: Glow in the F*cking Dark
books.author: Tara Schuster
books.review: I applaud Tara's commitment to healing and sharing her vulnerability. I didn't love this one as much as "buy yourself the fking lilies" but I think that's because I've done a lot of self reflection and most of her advice in her first book was about "re-parenting" herself (aka how to be an adult), which is still hard for me (how do people keep their kitchens clean all the time?!) My heart broke for little Tara and her brutal childhood. I want to give her the biggest hug. I love that she touches on money issues. I have LOTS of money issues and I felt deeply seen. I am inspired to examine this about myself instead of pretending it doesn't exist. I'll have to call my buddy khe hy too... She didn't wait for anyone to give her permission, she just started being the person she wanted to be. I love that for her and want that for me!!

books.title: Between Two Kingdoms: A Memoir of a Life Interrupted
books.author: Suleika Jaouad
books.review: This memoir is achingly beautiful. The writing is like butter. 3/28/23 It's 7:30 am and it's snowing a lot. It snowed a lot overnight too. We have a cute little rover with us this week, an Australian Labradoodle named Sadie. She's very high energy. I am sitting on the couch drinking coffee with raw milk as it dumps snow. Coziness level 10/10. Taylor Swift's "Lavender Haze" is stuck in my head. I don't even like that song very much. Is that James Vincent McMorrow on vocals in the background? I can't tell. I finished listening to "Between Two Kingdoms" yesterday. It's a memoir written by a half Tunisian, half Swiss woman, named Suleika Jaouad, (by the way, Suleika is perhaps the most beautiful name that I have ever heard - and it means "most beautiful woman") who gets diagnosed with leukemia at age 22. Most of the book is about her experience with chemo and frequent hospitalizations. The last bit of her book is kind of like her version of "Wild," where she road trips across the country meeting the people that wrote her letters when she was sick. I could not put her story down. There were many negative Goodreads reviews that called her selfish and privileged. Are there some contractions she doesn't address? Attending Princeton - supposedly only because she received a full scholarship. Yet, her parents own an apartment in the East Village in Manhattan that she stays in during her treatment. Her parents also own a cabin in Vermont. She also played the double bass growing up, an instrument that certainly wasn't offered at my public school... But to the point about her being selfish - give me a break! She acknowledges that sickness robs you of your humanity and she knew she wasn't the best version of herself. How can you not be self consumed when dealing with life or death? Why do I love to read negative Goodreads reviews?! I used to think it was only applicable when I also hated the book but I've realized that I seek them out even when I love the book. I guess I just love reading dissenting opinions. After I finish a book, I go into a rabbit hole about the author. The fact that her "Jon" is JON FREAKING BATISTE - are you kidding me?! Who meets Jon Batiste at band camp at age 13?! Obsessed. We played "Freedom" at our wedding and it was pure joy. Everyone thinks "Will" - her boyfriend that stays with her through her diagnosis and bears the brunt of caretaking duties - deserves more recognition. Again, I feel like she did this. She acknowledged how much he did for her, but she also wrote about how she felt (this is her memoir people!) I listened to her interview on "Mom's Don't Have Time to Read Books" (how does Zibby read so many damn books, someone please explain also, didn't know Zibby could be a name either) and she mentioned that Melissa Febos was her advisor - which 100% tracks because both authors write with such elegance and beauty that it makes me want to set myself on fire because I will never be able to write like that. She also said Cheryl Strayed told her that "we write the book we were meant to write, not the book we want to write." How can I get these same women to advise me, sheesh! I loved the book. I love the idea of turning pain/illness into art. Writing is my form of processing as well, even though I have never experienced any trauma so I tell myself that my writing is not "real." One con: I will admit this book was way too long. I kept listening and was like "how am I only X% of the way through!!" So yes, the editing could have been better. But at the same time, I was never bored, I was enthralled by her story and her writing. A must read IMO! OH! I'd be REMISS if I forgot to mention infertility!!! How in the HOLY HELL is it okay for people not to be told that they are going to be infertile post chemo? She said she used Fertile Hope to freeze her eggs. I used to babysit for a woman, Joyce, who was employee #2 at Fertile Hope, a company started by Lindsay Beck. Beck got tongue cancer at age 22 and was appalled when she found out that NO ONE WAS PLANNING ON TELLING HER THAT POST TREATMENT, SHE'D NEVER BE ABLE TO BEAR CHILDREN. I must dedicate my life to this cause. Beck's mission was to make it a law that doctors had to mention this to patients and she succeeded. But the fact that Suleika had to bring this issue up herself shows that MORE MUST BE DONE. You can't just bury infertility as a list of side effects!! This must be discussed. And another fun fact is that fertility treatment isn't covered by insurance! Isn't being a woman the best!? And being a woman with cancer is just the cherry on top. So now the woman I used to babysit for dedicates her life to ensuring fertility preservation is covered by insurance. What have I been doing with my life? Finance and business operations for tech companies? When Joyce is out there crusading for women and literally making dreams come true? I feel like the scum of the earth. How do I help!?

books.title: The Measure
books.author: Nikki Erlick
books.review: I was intrigued throughout even though I don't usually enjoy books with a bunch of different narrators. It was a page turner. I didn't care that much about the romance story lines but they didn't detract. Lots of interesting moral questions raised. I don't think I would look at my string but I'm torn!!!

books.title: BFF: A Memoir of Friendship Lost and Found
books.author: Christie Tate
books.review: I enjoyed her first book, "Group" (even though it was annoying because she was OBSESSED with finding a man and it got OLD and her therapist sounds incredibly problematic...) because she gave a voice to a lot of thoughts that make me feel defective for feeling. It is nice to read the petty stuff - she fully admits to friendship jealousy and judgement that I feel like I am not supposed to feel. It brought up lots of uncomfortable stuff about my friendship breakups...

books.title: Life Will Be the Death of Me: . . . and you too!
books.author: Chelsea Handler
books.review: I loved it! She looked herself in the mirror and actually tried to decipher what she thought about herself. The stuff about her brother and her childhood was tough. I would love to hang out with her. She's so fun.

books.title: Have I Told You This Already?: Stories I Don‚Äôt Want to Forget to Remember
books.author: Lauren Graham
books.review: The story about her dog and her mother is so touching. I love her essays and completely agree that Nora should not have had to worry about her neck!! TIL that celebrity talk shows are scripted!! So disappointed.

books.title: What Made Maddy Run: The Secret Struggles and Tragic Death of an All-American Teen
books.author: Kate Fagan
books.review: Would this story have been written if Maddy was not a beautiful, Ivy league athlete? Absolutely not. But I, too, fell into the trap of "but she was so pretty" - as if being good looking makes you immune to the difficulties of life. I see a lot of myself in Maddy. I have never handled failure well. School made sense to me. I have always equated my self worth to an external marker, first grades, now salary. To me, self worth depended on success. I am just now realizing that self esteem may fluctuate but self worth is steady - a deep knowing that you are enough. Right now this concept is abstract but I'm working towards a base level of self regard, that does not rely on external success factors. Maddy was a freshman at Penn on the track team who killed herself in January 2014 (eerily on my birthday...) I don't remember her but I probably read a headline about her back then. This book has softened my stance on athletes and mental health - or more broadly fame/pressure and mental health. I used to think that it was complete bullshit that Simone Biles dropped out of the most recent Olympics due to "mental health." I did not see this as a heroic act in the slightest. I saw it as a cop out because she wasn't doing as well as she wanted. But I found it hypocritical because she had been ALL over tv cashing in on the upcoming Olympics. She was in soooo many ads. So I was very annoyed when she dropped out. She should have to give all that endorsement money back! What a fraud! Same with Naomi Osaka, the tennis star. Same with Jonah Hill - you can't just opt out of doing PR - that's part of your job! But after listening to the first chunk of this book, I have a lot more empathy. First, I had forgotten how unbelievably disorienting and stressful freshman year of college was. I had a really hard time. I have repressed these memories and reframed college as a magical time. But it certainly was not. I stopped sleeping. I stopped going to the bathroom (I will never forgive Cal for its co-ed bathrooms - HORRIBLE). I had no idea how to feed myself. I discovered pretzel goldfish in the Unit 3 grab and go section of the cafeteria. I felt like a complete fraud and failure. I didn't get into the "right" sorority. I didn't know what to major in. I didn't get straight A's. It was brutal. The pressure was relentless. And at the same time, I wasn't under any pressure but I felt like I was drowning. After working so hard in high school to get to college, I felt completely bereft. I had no map to follow. Life had been so prescribed - take AP classes, play sports, do extra curricular - all to get into the best college you can to eventually get the best job you can. But how were those four years supposed to go? Well I was "supposed" to apply to the business school but I was too intimidated. Everyone at Cal was so self assured. My roommate was a double major (she ended up not graduating with either of those majors but at the time I felt like I was supposed to know what to do). I am still perplexed by those who came in as declared engineering majors. What is engineering? I still don't know. How did they know they wanted to be engineers??? A friend of mine tried to transfer into engineering and didn't get in. So really you have to know before you even apply. So at age 17 you must know that you want to be an engineer. But there are no engineering classes in high school. Someone please make it make sense! It has to be that their parents were engineers. So if you're parents aren't engineers, you will never be one. Another friend came in declared as an EECS major - electrical engineering and computer science - what is electrical engineering!? I made one friend that wasn't in my sorority freshman year. She had dropped out of sorority rush because she hated it. She left Cal after freshman year and transferred to UC Irvine to be near home. She told me how much she hated Cal and I tried to encourage her to join a sorority because that had been the only method for me to make friends. The school was simply too big and overwhelming. Berkeley didn't give a shit about you. If you didn't try exceedingly hard, you would surly be swept under. Maddy feels similarly swallowed by Penn. It seems like everyone else is effortlessly gliding along when you are drowning. I've never had suicidal ideations - for the most part, sometimes things do get really dark but never to the point where I think of taking my own life - sometimes I do want to just sleep forever though. This is the thing I realized - you truly never know what someone else is feeling. What is a "good day" to someone else compared to your version? What do I know about the pressure that Simone Biles was feeling? I will NEVER know how she was feeling - because you can never truly get inside someone else's head. It's easy to sneer and judge - pressure is part of the job of being a famous athlete/actor! But I truly will never know the stories that their brains are telling them and it's their life so they get to make their own decisions. It's so easy for me to look at beautiful Madison Holleran and say, "if only she had just held on and gotten help." But the voices in her head were too loud. Life is hard but it is so so worth it. I want to be alive so much. I am so sad for those who do not get to keep having birthdays. They remind me how much I treasure life. They remind me to breathe deeply and to not hold back. I don't want to play it safe and follow the rules. I want to live my life in a way that aligns with my values. They remind me that nothing is guaranteed. Even if I wake up groggy and cranky and I haven't been sleeping well. I can snuggle my sweet perfect dog. I can drink coffee and watch the snow fall. I can hug my wonderful husband. I have built this sweet little life and I truly cherish it. I don't want to ruminate on my imperfections. Don't regret growing older, it's a privilege denied to many. Heres are some quotes that stuck out to me: Of course, what remained hard to understand was the effect this would have on Madison's psyche. She had never handled failure, even the garden-variety kind, well. During high school, Madison once finished fourth in the 400 hurdles at a county meet—much worse than expected. She started crying and asked to leave the event, even before cooling down. "She had a tremendous work ethic, and she worked hard at everything she did," Stacy said. "**But she just put so much pressure on herself."** In high school, Madison won constantly, and that steady stream of victories strengthened her fragile psyche. But once she was at Penn, Jim and Stacy, along with her older sister Carli, began to notice the erosion of Madison's confidence. When Maddy was in middle school, she would walk to school in the mornings with kids in the neighborhood. As the year went on, she started timing how long the walk took. Once she had that specific number, she needed the next day to be faster, and the day after that, faster still. By the end of the year, she was speed-walking, occasionally breaking into a jog, to beat the previous day's time. **There was something satisfying, calming almost, about controlling time and output in this way. She had created these little tests for herself, ones that she was fairly certain she could pass.** **Maddy was addicted to progress, to the idea that her life would move in one vector—always forward, always improving—as opposed to the hills and valleys, the sideways and backward and upside down, that adults eventually learn to accept as more closely resembling reality.** Maddy was not unique in feeling this way. Much of young adulthood is presented as a ladder, each rung closer to success, or whatever our society has defined as success. Perhaps climbing the ladder is tiring, but it is not confusing. You are never left wondering if you've made the wrong choice, or expended energy in the wrong direction, because there is only the one rung above you. Get good grades. Get better at your sport. Take the SAT. Do volunteer work. Apply to colleges. Choose a college. But then you get to college, and suddenly you're out of rungs and that ladder has turned into a massive tree with hundreds of sprawling limbs, and progress is no longer a thing you can easily measure, because there are now thousands of paths to millions of destinations. And none are linear. School had always been straightforward: collect a specific set of numbers and letters, and receive your desired grade. That was not confusing; that was reassuring. In high school, she had the perfect—well, everything," Justine said. "She always stood out. But now, she wasn't fully seeing her success, or all of her work paying off. **Maddy often expected the worst.** To her, the prospect of failing out of Penn did not feel like hyperbole; it felt like the probable outcome. How could she believe otherwise, when she had no concrete evidence to the contrary? Everything had been flipped on its head, had become abstract. She was finishing behind a hundred other runners and was told that was good. She knew only half the answers on an art history test and was told not to panic. Freshman year of college, especially for those playing a sport, is like walking through an obstacle course wearing a blindfold. No context exists for how hard the workouts will be, how long they will last, what each class will be like, what events are fun, what should be avoided. There is no yin-yang, either; no understanding that one week might feel grueling, unmanageable, but just hang on, because the following week will be light and easy. **For someone who struggles with the unknown, freshman year of college can feel like walking a path lined with land mines—heart racing, disaster around every corner.** Now add another variable: mental health.

books.title: A Heart That Works
books.author: Rob Delaney
books.review: How can you rate this book? Don't read it on a Saturday night or on any night. Gutted. Can't stop sobbing. Life is so awful.

books.title: Drinking Games
books.author: Sarah Levy
books.review: Is she insanely privileged? (Therapy 2x/week, an MFA program, manifestation workshops...) Yes. Did I enjoy her memoir? Also yes. It felt like my memoir. Makes me want to quit drinking. I wonder what school she went to before transferring to Brown and what start up she worked at. Wish she talked more about the mechanics of getting sober and things like going to bachelorette parties sober. Loved her part on manifestation and contentment. # 2/18/23 - "Drinking Games" Book Review One week ago, on Saturday, February 11th, I read the book, "Drinking Games" by Sarah Levy in one sitting. It was truly my memoir. As I mentioned, I begin each year devouring "quit-lit" books - which are memoirs about getting sober. The fact that this is a pattern I repeat annually should tell me something that I clearly do not want to acknowledge. "I was starving for outside approval in all areas and drinking and getting dressed were no exception. I wanted to wear the cool labels in middle school and drink the right way in high school. I paid attention to my peers and shapeshifted so I would fit in. I sought out short-term gratification in miniskirts and tequila shots and hoped they would make me feel desirable, but the next morning I still felt like an imposter. Like my drinking, I struggled with moderation when it came to my clothes; nothing was ever enough. I was either wearing the same skinny jeans every weekend or drunkenly online shopping every night. When I was spit out into the "real world" at twenty-two, I felt vulnerable and lost, so I kept hiding in my clothes and cups." Levy's struggles with body image, self love, friendship, relationships, clothing, wellness, work all mirror my own thoughts about wanting to fit in and be accepted. Essentially she would shape shift in order to be liked. Quitting drinking allowed her the space to actually take stock of who she was and who she wanted to be. She let go of the noise of who she "should be" in order to fit in. So much of the messaging towards females is: be small, be quiet, be pretty, dress well, have a lot of friends, and most importantly, have a partner - do NOT be alone. Capitalism and social media sends you a barrage of images that say "YOU ARE NOT ENOUGH." You are not thin enough, you are not rich enough, you are not luxurious enough. Without this cream, this vacation to Europe, this engagement ring, you are broken, wrong, inferior to others. She had some profound insights that felt like lightbulbs flashing in my brain. A few revelations: - **How you dress is a reflection of how much you value yourself.** Brain explodes! She details her fraught relationship with clothing. She was raised to see clothing as a frivolous interest, as was I. Shopping has always been such a loaded topic and endeavor. My mother dresses like a blind bat. She loves teal so everything she owns is teal. She thinks it's perfectly acceptable to pear tight teal leggings with teal clogs and a teal scarf. All this to say, my mother and I do not share the same fashion tastes. I grew up shopping at the nearby TJ Maxx. We went to Mervyns for back to school shopping. These are not places that specialize in quality clothing. This is bottom of the barrel shopping. We weren't poor but clothing was not prioritized. My mom's email address is couponlady (couponqueen was taken) and it shows. She often gets money back after a Safeway trip. She won't buy anything that is not on sale. This is how I live my life - the cheaper is better. One of my closest friends was not raised this way. She has absolutely no problem dropping top dollar on nice things. It makes my brain explode. How does she justify it??? Does she think she deserves nice things?? At my bachelorette party, I was using a device the is a blow dryer that is also a round brush so it gives you a blow out type effect. I bought mine for $20 at TJ Maxx (it was my 2nd or 3rd because surprise surprise cheap stuff doesn't last that long??) My friend said "what a wonderful device I want one!" She went home and ordered one from Drybar (which I wrongly confused with Dyson so I thought she had spent $500+ on device she saw once and wanted). The Drybar one is not nearly as expensive as the Dyson one, but it is still 5x what I was spending on myself. And she didn't give this a second thought. She discovered Vuori clothing (soft AF clothing from San Diego) and didn't bat an eye at buying 5 things. I agonized for well over a year at buying one pair of pants. Why am I this why?? Why do I feel that I am underserving?? My friend has tons of cute Paige jeans that are perfectly tailored to her body. I have a few pairs that do not fit me because I bought them at Nordstrom Rack and therefore they are not in a fit or style that I like. WHY? I can't seem to grasp that I am worth investing in nice things. It truly hurts my soul to spend money on myself. It's a problem. Shopping makes me feel wracked with guilt. I took a look at my closet last night and realized that every other piece was given to me by someone who didn't want it. I have multiple huge purple puffy jackets that I absolutely never would have picked out by choice. But they work! They keep me warm. Isn't that enough!? I am grateful that people chose to give them to me. The remainder of my clothes that are not hand me downs are from the little girls section of Old Navy. Not only do I only think I deserve clothes from Old Navy (not shade it's just not where anyone else I know on the planet shops because they all think it is beneath them), but I also do not think I deserve women's clothing. I save by buying clearance items from the girls section. This feels very sad to actually type out. I convince myself that I have figured out a secret money saving loophole because I am petite and can get away with buying XL or XXL girls clothing. But really what this means is that nothing I own is nice and form fitting. It's mostly bag type clothing made for 14 year old girls. I am 31 years old. Why can't I allow myself to dress like one? I want to be able to tuck in my tops to my (ill-fitting) jeans but since all of my clothes are loose, this looks terrible. Getting dressed is very disheartening because I truly do not like anything I own. I know I need to change how I view myself but my self worth is so conditional. I don't have a consistent stream of self worth. I have been trying to read this book "Good Morning, I Love You" for what feels like 100 years and in it the author describes how self esteem is fleeting and conditional, while self compassion is steady and consistent. I do not know how to not be fleeting. Everyday is a new roller coaster of torture. I wake up - if I don't work out then I am a failure and my day is ruined. If I don't eat "clean" (no sugar, no dairy, no grains, no alcohol), then I am a failure. If I don't "accomplish" anything, then I am a failure. So every day I feel like a complete and total failure. I have a habit tracker in my bullet journal and every week I tell myself I am going to the following daily: Exercise, Eat Clean, Write, Meditate, Floss, Walk 10k steps. I write this out weekly in a grid and check a box for each daily activity. I haven't meditated...well ever and yet I have been writing this same grid out for 3+ years. I don't "celebrate" wins, I ruminate in losses. It is incredibly demoralizing. And yet I can't stop. I listened to the audio version of the book "The Bullet Journal Method" at the end of 2018 when we were roadtripping in New Zealand and I felt like I had found the solution to my life's problems. I love planners but I have always struggled to find the "right" one. Now I could make my own! And I could track everything! The point was to help create better habits so you could get closer to your goals and to record how you actually spend your time so you could see your current self more clearly. The point was not to trap yourself in a weekly grid of self loathing. But yet here we are. I take most things and turn it into a cage. Why? How to stop? Bullet journaling felt great in the beginning because I LOVE structure. I still get a dopamine high when I set up my week on Sunday. It is sooo soothing to see the week in nice little boxes. But then I discovered "life logging" and I turned a good thing into a weapon. A blogger I Love, "The Unconventional Route," started recording everything he does throughout the day to get a clearer picture of how he spends his time. So if he scrolled mindlessly on his phone for 3 hours, he'd log that. It's great to start holding yourself accountable. You can't change what you can't measure or whatever the saying is. But I turned this idea into a food diary. I have been writing down everything I eat for the past few years. It's not a calorie tracker. But it might as well be. I write down what I do too (though not to the same granular level that he does, I do not write down when I lose hours scrolling because I don't want to see myself THAT clearly). I have journaled my whole life but I realize that I have been doing it all wrong. I don't tap into my feelings, I simply log what I did that day. I always think it's a good idea to read old journal entries and it NEVER is. Instead of gaining insight into my previous mindset, all I am left with is, "I slept over at Julia's house, then I went to swim practice." Who the fuck cares? What did I talk about at the sleepover, what was on my mind? No clue. And I'm still doing this same unhelpful practice to this day. This is why I feel that I am not a writer and will never be a writer because I am still too afraid to actually form opinions and reflections. I am simply a court stenographer. I transcribe events. No more, no less. And who wants to read that? Nobody. Not even me. OOF so that was a tangent from clothing but it clearly needed to come out. I struggle with self worth and all the self help books have not "fixed" me. This brings me back to more golden nuggets from "Drinking Games." - **It's an inside job. There is no quick fix solution.** Everyday you have to make the decision to act how you want to feel. I heard this in a meeting a week ago: "mood follows action." BOOM. After the meeting, I went to Albertsons and immediately consumed a ton of junk food and I felt...bad? I heard her say mood follows action but I still didn't do the right action. How does one do it??? "Whenever I bought a new beauty product or supplement, I got high on the same strain of hope. This, I always thought, would finally fix me. This moisturizer changed my life, every online review read, and I believed it every time." "I wanted a body that was lean, long, thin, fit, active, strong, fast, tight, tucked, and skin that was plump, glowing, bouncy, dewy, and hydrated. Like my drinking, it was all too much and never enough. I was bottoming out on wellness, I realized. But I wasn't sure I was ready to walk away from it. Wellness had been a pleasant distraction and safe catch-all for my feelings for the better part of a decade. Whenever I felt angry, hurt, or sad, I focused on my weight instead of digging into the root of my feelings. I had wrapped my identity around drinking and changing my body, and I wondered what would be left of me if I unraveled this thread too." Hmmmm....interesting. So maybe my obsession with my weight is a distraction and a refusal to acknowledge my feelings? OOF this feels to raw and tender to investigate. I love/hate realizing things when I write. That feels like such a stupid realization but honestly I have never put that together. My obsession with food is a distraction from my feelings. Huh. I mean, I know the reason I binge eat is to numb so I don't know why this jump feels enlightening but it does. Because I don't binge eat every day. So I only feel truly awful when I do but I'm realizing that even though I don't binge eat daily, I still feel terrible daily because I am obsessed with tracking my food and feeling like I "should" be eating "better/cleaner." HMMM. Maybe I should stop tracking my food??? THIS FEELS VERY SCARY. BUT MY CONTROL. What control though?? Gah. "I also began to think critically about my relationship with wellness and alcohol. My quest for nirvana through wellness had not been unlike my pursuit of drunkenness. I thought of both as elixirs that could fix me quickly, and with little real work on my part. I would have bought anything the wellness industry told me would make me glow, strut, and sleep better. Similarly, alcohol touted a promise of ease, relaxation, and confidence. Both worlds promoted the idea of balance (Drink responsibly!) while shirking any real responsibility for outcomes (Consult a doctor before beginning a new fitness regimen!). There's no time for consultations or responsible consumption when you're trying to change everything about yourself." - **Wellness is really just another synonym for diet!** What! Yeah drinking juices and obsessing over "whole foods" and such is really just another diet. I know it's supposed to be about "lifestyle" but really it's just a cover up for diet. "I heard people in my recovery meetings say that hitting bottom doesn't have to be catastrophic; it can simply mean that we are ready to stop digging. I was ready to stop living in my wellness hole. But this meant admitting something I had never said out loud before: in my world, wellness had just been a fancy word for diet. Underneath the gloss of new products and promises, all I had ever wanted was to be small, and look like all the other girls." This all reminds me of Caroline Knapp's (the OG quit lit author) book, "Appetites." She details how all women have a vacuous hole that they seek to fill with one of three things: food, clothes and men. It feel insultingly reductive but it is ON THE NOSE. "My clean clothes and streamlined wardrobe helped me signal that I was more confident in my identity when I stopped drinking. But getting dressed was just one way I learned to care for myself in sobriety. My mornings were another, a quiet stretch of time with coffee and my journal before starting the workday. Daily walks with no destination were also a favorite, just me and a good podcast or playlist. For other people, self-care might look like cooking more meals at home, joining a softball team, or painting. It doesn't matter, really. It all comes back to the same place: recognizing that, now, you have a choice in how you spend your time and present yourself. Without alcohol, I had the space to figure out who I was and how I wanted to walk through my life. The chic boots I wore along the way were just a bonus."

books.title: Easy Crafts for the Insane: A Mostly Funny Memoir of Mental Illness and Making Things
books.author: Kelly Williams Brown
books.review: She is so delightful and her writing is engaging, even about really heavy topics. I appreciate her honesty and vulnerability.

books.title: Luckiest Girl Alive
books.author: Jessica Knoll
books.review: At first this read like a book I would have loved in middle school/high school (gossip girl or the clique) but then the shooting happened. Woah I did not see that coming. It was very hard to read given all of the school shootings and mass violence we see every day on the news. I am pleased with the ending. I was hooked and needed to tear through every chapter.

books.title: Call of the Mild: Learning to Hunt My Own Dinner
books.author: Lily Raff McCaulou
books.review: I enjoyed this book. Mostly because it's based in Bend but also because it offers a different take on hunting. My brother and dad are lifelong hunters but I've never understood the appeal. The author highlights a lot of uncomfortable truths about the meat we consume. Her writing is engaging and personal despite being full of stats that I ordinarily wouldn't have been interested in. This made me want to be a journalist. Interesting how hunting is almost meditative to her, she's not zoned out or anxious. Reminded me that I want to learn more about my environment.

books.title: Razorblade Tears
books.author: S.A. Cosby
books.review: Hmm. I'm in the minority I guess. Did not work for me. Gratuitous violence in the name of characters we never got to know/had no attachment to. When we find out who the leads are looking for, I was unmoved. The way the "puzzle pieces came together" did not do it for me. The ending was way too neat. I don't see many redeeming qualities about this story.

books.title: Good for a Girl: A Woman Running in a Man's World
books.author: Lauren Fleshman
books.review: Amazon randomly pushed the book "Radically Content" by Jamie Varon on my Kindle so I downloaded it from the library and I LOVED IT. I wanted to devour all the Jamie Varon content I could find so I listened to a bunch of podcasts where she was a guest. This is how I discovered Nicole Antoinette and her podcasts (Real Talk Radio & The Pop Up Pod), which are both amazing. After my Jamie Varon rabbit hole, I fell into a Nicole Antoinette rabbit hole. Lauren Fleshman is a guest on Nicole's podcast and I really enjoyed her episodes. I discovered that Nicole used to live in Bend and Lauren currently does! Which is so fun because I had just moved to Bend. I tried to read more of Lauren Fleshman's writing by going to her blog ([asklaurenfleshman.com](http://asklaurenfleshman.com/)) but sadly, it looks like they took it down and replaced it with a website promoting this book. I find this very irritating because I want to read more of Lauren's writing!! (I messaged her on Twitter about this and she did not respond lol) I read her book because I liked her perspective on Nicole's podcast. I read and appreciated her opinion piece for the NYT "I Changed My Body for My Sport. No Girl Should." I also read Mary Cain's piece, "I Was the Fastest Girl in America, Until I Joined Nike," which was equally eye opening and disheartening. I am the target audience of "Good for a Girl." It didn't hurt that she was going to be speaking at my local bookstore later this month. So I ordered a pre-order copy (which she signed). I am a Kindle girl. Kendall the Kindle girl. I will force anyone who will listen to buy a kindle. So this was interesting because I can't even remember the last time I read a physical book. Honestly, it made me miss my Kindle. Hardcovers are so bulky! Okay enough preamble...oh I remember why I wrote this because now to remember the quotes I loved (which I had to use a physical highlighter for!), I need to go fetch my physical copy and dig them up. I should also mention that I am distance runner. I run recreationally and really struggle to even identify myself as a "runner" because I am not skinny and I did not run track or cross country in high school. I don't know why I have decided that those are the only qualifiers to be a runner. I have done 3 marathons, 3 half marathons and 2 triathlons (sprint distance, I always must discount things that I should be proud of...I have issues). I am running a marathon in April and my goal is to qualify for Boston (the route is not a Boston qualifying race but I need a goal to work toward!) Yet I still refuse to call myself a runner. So it was really nice to read that even Lauren Fleshman, the definition of a RUNNER, struggles with feeling worthy/deserving certain titles as well. I know I am the target audience but I wish more people would read this book besides people like me. I wish my husband would read this book but I know he won't! UGH. Here are some golden nuggets: (I marked this review as having spoilers because of my highlights although I don't think any of these really spoil the book at all) - "Women made great men possible. What made great women possible? Avoiding the vortex of a man's ambition? Being alone?" (page 73) - [Referring to the Stanford mens team] "They were focused on battling the competition. We spent so much of our competitive energy battling ourselves." (page 84) - "In obsessing about the scale and how I looked, I was outsourcing my confidence." (page 105) - "One definition of privilege is who gets to make mistakes." (page 115) - "If there had been intentional space made in sports for menstrual health and symptom management by coaches and staff, I would have viewed my cycle as something to learn from and work with, instead of as a limiting inconvenience that made me resent my female body." (page 118) *!!! This. I resent my female body ALL THE TIME.* - "She listened, and I found that allowing her to be a witness to my worries defused them, whereas trying not to think about them made them louder." (page 144) - Making everything about winning, about the Olympics, about being the best..it felt BAD. Not just when things went wrong, but most of the time, The industry's emphasis on outcomes placed no value on the things that made me fall in love with running in the first place...the simple pleasure of mastering a skill...any pursuit of excellence had to center these moments of joy, or it wasn't worth doing." (page 196) - "Having clarity around who you are, what you stand for, and how you want to be understood is not egotistical. It's a chance to take stock of things and be intentional. It's going to be good for life, too, not just in sports. Let's get to the core of who you are and what you want." - "I want to tell a sports story in a different, more human, more honest way, in real time, and not wait for someone else to tell it. I want to tell it as I go, and not wait to see if I'm ‚Äòsuccessful' or not, because I want to expand the definition of success beyond traditional outcomes." (page 197) !!! - Those were things i could do that didn't depend on my physical body being 100% perfect all the time. I could always tell stories and build communities. Maybe they would give people a story to follow, making the highs more exciting. Maybe they would make the lows a little less lonely and painful for me when they happened. And maybe storytelling and community building would make the transition out of sports easier one day." (page 197) - "But I found that the more honest I was, the more readers engaged positively, too. My blog gave me something to look forward to every day that wasn't running." (page 203) - "How interesting that a visual cue like these race buns could hijack the mind so easily. These little briefs that only women were expected to wear were essentially designed for that purpose, to make female athletes objects of displace. Feminine uniforms were created to assuage fears that sport and femininity were at odds, and as an entertaining consolation for audiences for watching ‚Äòinferior performances' Uniform guidelines mandating exposed skin and ‚Äòformfitting' silhouettes for only one gender must have been coded into rule books across many sports. in others, they have been internalized as symbols of professionalism by the women themselves—the high heels of the running world—but instead of back pain, you get body dysmorphia."
