(page 206) *GUT PUNCH.* - "I didn't have these athletic role models yet, but I was trying in my own way, to be one. When I broke my navicular and narrowly missed the Olympics, and was unsure if I'd return to what I loved, I looked for guidance everywhere online. What do you do when things fall apart? How do you continue trying when the likelihood of success is so slim? How do you make yourself vulnerable after heartache? I found these stories in literature, in the lives of fictional characters, but I couldn't find these real-time stories in sports. Athletes weren't telling them. They weren't talking unless they were winning, reflecting back on rough times long gone. I needed the material that would help me take one more step forward without the promise of a happy ending. So I wrote it myself. (page 211) *MIC DROP.* - "...I wanted to provide at least one person's accurate representation of chasing big goals for the next person who searched the internet during a low point...The more my life expanded off the track, the more satisfied I was on it." (page 211) - "Four years ago, I bought into the idea that all that mattered was the Olympics. I lived like the running monk everyone told me to be, and it killed the joy of everything. Since then, I've defined success for myself and I do it my own way. I reject the idea that all that matters is becoming an Olympian." (page 218) - "This isn't the ending I dreamed of, sure. But when you realized failing doesn't make you a failure, you give yourself permission to try all sorts of things." (page 218) *!!! Big star next to the highlight!!* - "Because I hate that I felt good about it until everyone else showed up. I hate giving that power to anyone. I've spent so much time wiring about how it's all about the journey or whatever, and now I feel full of shit. ‚ÄòIt's easy to say it's all about the journey when you're winning.'" (page 219) - "It was yet another reminder that people are hungry for the truth, and that the truth spurs liberation." (page 238) - "My priority was getting my athletes to stop outsourcing their key decision-making, to trust themselves, to take the wheel and drive their running and their lives." (page 247) - "I was able to hear these messages we tell ourselves for what they are: violence." (page 249) - "Every woman who lost confidence and self-worth for ‚Äòfailing' to progress. Every woman who couldn't eat without having ‚Äòearned it' and turned to exercise as punishment to atone for indulgence. (page 250) *Me*... - "I had felt angry with the women who developed eating disorders or made choices that hurt their health or our teams' prospects. Now I was angry that so many women and girls were blamed for not thriving in a system not truly built for them." (page 250) - "We need adults to deal with their own issues around food and body so they don't pas them on to the children and young adults in their care. (page 258) *Hi mom!* - "We need passionate leaders of all genders to take women's sports into the next fifty years and beyond. But we also need stories. A flood of them. the invisible and the forbidden. The small stuff that adds up to big change." (page 258) - "While it had taken me some time to realized it or call it by its name, my whole life I had been engaging in the hard work of learning to run for myself, not for others. I had been learning how to return to myself, again and again, in a world full of forces that consistently pull us away. I wanted to hold tight to that knowledge; even more strongly, I wanted to pass it on." (page 260) Omg typing all of those quotes up was exhausting. So grateful for my Kindle that I never have to do this again lol. I don't usually share my highlights publicly on Goodreads but this analog method left me no choice. I don't have the energy to reflect on all of my favorite quotes right now. Perhaps I will return to this review and update it. Because I have a lot of thoughts. Basically I echo everything Lauren says. The world is unfair. Being a woman has a lot of drawbacks, but the world needs to start changing to accommodate the fact that men and women are different!! Lauren mentions the book "Invisible Women" by Caroline Criado P√©rez, which I couldn't finish because It was just SO DAMN DEPRESSING. Nothing in this world is set up with women in mind. Nothing is set up for our bodies. We are second class citizens and it makes me want to SET MYSELF ON FIRE.

books.title: Local Woman Missing
books.author: Mary Kubica
books.review: Hmm...too many coincidences (two missing girls that look almost identical and are the same age?) and Meredith was too dumb to believe. And why wouldn't B just kill Delilah? Why even keep her alive? I feel unfulfilled.

books.title: A Good Marriage
books.author: Kimberly McCreight
books.review: Last night I finished the book, "A Good Marriage." For most of the book, I was rapt. The writing was smart and fast (to me, many GoodReads reviews said it was a slow build). But I found the ending dissatisfying. I read this book because of a recently discovered podcast, "Pop Fiction Women." Earlier this month, I watched an episode of "Fleishman Is In Trouble" titled "This Is My Enjoyment" (episode 6 of the mini-series based on a book I really enjoyed) and felt like I HAD to discuss it with someone. The episode made me feel seen because it centers on someone struggling with the transition to middle age and clinging to who she used to be and who she wanted to be. She is disillusioned with who she had become. I searched Spotify for discussions on the tv show/book and stumbled upon this podcast. I learned that the two hosts are old law school friends who live in New York and love to read. They also love Sally Rooney and Fleabag, so I figured I could trust their taste. I was so happy because I have been struggling to find book inspiration. I have loathed books from Reese's Book Club. I read Goodreads reviews of books that I enjoyed then I stalk the reading lists of the reviewers that I agree with. This works 60% of the time but I wanted to up my odds. My issue with "A Good Marriage" is that there are so many loose ends that were not resolved!! Also I thought the ending was sloppy. 1. The reveal of killer/the twist. Kerry was such a minor part of the book but he decides that instead of going to the sex party with his wife, he would instead play basketball but then attend the party on a whim and harass Amanda via text. - Then the author is super murky on what actually lead to her death in his written confession. He has a ski mask in his gym bag and decides to attack her to scare her and then his plan was to console her? How would this have panned out?? How do you attack someone then switch into the savior? Would he have left and then ditched the mask and returned? I don't get it. - He also states that he and Amanda had a relationship which is never touched on in the book. Is it a lie? Or did the author just not include the reader in on this part? We see Amanda's perspective and in no way do they seem to have a relationship. - The ending was just so rushed and non sensical. Kerry is an ex partner at Lizzie's new firm and he was fired before she started? Because he stalked women and said "if you'd just listen to me"? And he supposedly had pornographic photos of these women? And worked with them? And then his wife finds out about his porn addiction from the cyber attacks that are orchestrated by Zach on their school? I just didn't follow his backstory. 2. Amanda's mental health. So if her father and best friend, Carolyn, are both dead, who is she spending time with when she is with them? Was someone really stalking her or was that just in her head? All those times when she was hanging out with or running with Carolyn, was she talking to herself? And no one ever noticed it? She only imagined people when she was alone and no one ever saw her? They never explained her mental state. 3. What was the deal with Amanda's uncle? Was he just a red herring? So many unanswered questions. I just listened to the podcast episode where they interview the author and one of the hosts, Carinn, says the book is very satisfying in the end. I could not disagree more. This is one of the most unsatisfying books I have read in a while. Lots of books end ambiguously and bother me. What bothers me more is that this one pretended that it answered all of the open questions but it most certainly did not. I need a book club where everyone loves and hates the same books as me. I tried to discuss my frustration with my husband and he gave no shits. "You know when you are engrossed in a thriller and then it leaves a lot of things unanswered?" "Yeah." "This woman thought she was being stalked by her dead father and regularly hung out with her dead best friend." "Uh huh." He told me I need to join a book club. But then I told him that I hate most "book club" books (like Reese's). I am going to join a book club that is starting next month but he told me I probably shouldn't join it because I am overly critical and I will end up losing friends. He's not wrong. I know some people on Goodreads share my sentiments but I need to discuss with people in person. I know I should not want people who share the exact same opinion as me but I want to love something and for others to share that love (and hate something and feel validated). End of rant.

books.title: Mother Daughter Widow Wife
books.author: Robin Wasserman
books.review: Engaging in the beginning but then I completely lost interest. Only finished to hit 50 books.

books.title: The Boys' Club
books.author: Erica Katz
books.review: Mindless. Entertaining enough I suppose. Very similar to "devil wears Prada."

books.title: Tell Me Everything: The Story of a Private Investigation
books.author: Erika Krouse
books.review: Heavy stuff. Had me weeping. Reminded me of "know my name." Made me hate football even more than I already did. My husband is a big dolphins fan and when I heard about what happened to Tua I was appalled. Then we got into a fight about CTE because "these players know what they are signed up for. Are you saying these players shouldn't play football for a chance to bring their families out of poverty?" At a cost of their brain? Yes, that is what I'm saying.. "Some players spoke with no affect at all, like low-voiced robots. Some players erupted in fury when they heard a question they didn't like, and then seemed to forget their rage immediately, friendly again. Most of the players I spoke with seemed confused. At that time, the Journal of the American Medical Association had not yet conducted their 2017 study of the brains of 202 deceased football players. They studied people who had played football in high school, college, and the NFL. They diagnosed chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), a degenerative brain disorder, in 21 percent of high school players and 91 percent of college football players. Among the 111 NFL players they studied, 110 had the disease, bringing the statistic up to over 99 percent. The longer you play, the worse the symptoms, which include aggression, ADHD, cognitive impairment, impulsive behavior, apathy, confusion, disorientation, dizziness, vertigo, headaches, social/emotional instability, personality changes, sensory processing disorder, speech impediments, balance issues, deafness, erratic/inappropriate/explosive behavior, pathological jealousy, paranoia, depression, progressive dementia, memory loss, amnesia, strokes, and suicidal ideation. Football players' chances of contracting dementia at any age were between 33 and 85 percent. But I didn't know any of this back then. I only knew what Calliope had told me: "These guys get hit in the head a lot. A lot. They don't always even understand what they're saying or doing. And then they forget immediately, like their brain is quicksand." I wondered what it was like to forget everything-everything bad that had ever happened to you, everything bad you ever did or watched someone else do. One player spent our conversation repeating that everything was "clean, aboveboard. Just a sports team at a party." After I gave up and said goodbye, he called me back a few moments later and said earnestly, "Erika, I just want you to know something. I've met hundreds of people in college programs. The stuff that happens here, well, that happens everywhere. Everywhere. It's just the general culture of recruiting trips." — Tried to comment the following on the 1 star review of "JanB" but we aren't friends so I can't: I honestly thought your profile was fake and made to discredit the book but it seems as though you are a real person. I've never wanted to fight with someone in the comments on goodreads before. So surprised at all these comments! "While I have the utmost sympathy for anyone who endures abuse, I just can't read about it anymore." What drew you to the book in the first place?

books.title: The Long Answer
books.author: Anna Hogeland
books.review: I am deeply afraid of motherhood so all I read now are books about motherhood.

books.title: The Rules Do Not Apply
books.author: Ariel Levy
books.review: I love her writing.

books.title: Body Work: The Radical Power of Personal Narrative
books.author: Melissa Febos
books.review: The first chapter of the book, "In Defense of Navel Gazing," hit the nail on the head for me. She tackles the persistent voice full of fear which says "Who cares?" I hear this voice every time I sit down to write. Instead of writing for me, I get lost writing for "them." These other people who will criticize my words and deem them unnecessary and trite. Melissa questions herself, "who are these other people?" and realizes that they are the people who have dismissed her or made her feel small and notes that these are the exact people that she does not write for. She does not value their opinion. She does not wish to associate with these people. So why does she let their opinion dictate the value of her writing? She explains that writing is a way of healing and learning from herself. It is a form of processing. This has always been true for me. Until I write something down, it sloshes around in my head and controls me. This is not to say that I am free of my thoughts as soon as I get them on the page, but they do lose a bit of their sting. This is why I am obsessive about bullet journaling. I write down what I do, what I eat, at what time. I feel lost if I get behind in my daily log. I feel anxious. It's like I am alone with my thoughts and trapped with them until I can get them "out." Then I can feel a bit of distance, a bit of breathing room. I struggle with the next step of learning from my thoughts. I am lacking in the analysis/reflection step. I can word vomit but then I can't look at what the vomit is telling me (gross). And if you can't learn what you ate that made you throw up, how will you ever get better? Ugh. See this is a learning process right now. I struggle to face my emotions. I can write them down but I can't process them. It feels too vulnerable and exposed. It feels like poking a wound. I must cover the wound and never address it. But then it never heals. It festers. It gets infected. It infects other parts of me. It inflames my immune system. I feel so fatigued. I feel so weighed down. I am so tired of feeling this way. How can I feel lighter? Am I just a narcissist? Am I that person they are referring to in the movie Easy A when they say "I don't know what your generation's fascination is with documenting your every thought... but I can assure you, they're not all diamonds. "Roman is having an OK day, and bought a Coke Zero at the gas station. Raise the roof." Who gives a rat's ass?" Aka am I a navel gazer who overshares but doesn't share anything of substance. Would anyone even want to read my blog or listen to my podcast!? Am I an asshole for thinking I am that interesting when I have accomplished exactly nothing in my life thus far!? Melissa Febos essentially busts this line of thinking but I can't help the way my toxic brain works against me! But in her TedTalk "Telling Your Secrets Can Set You Free" she says "transforming your personal experience into literary art is a process of creation. you don't just get to transcribe the events in the order that they happened. you describe the events and then you have to look at them you have to meet the gaze of your past self and ask her the questions that sometimes we spend our whole lives avoiding asking and then you have to listen to her answers"

books.title: Acne
books.author: Laura Chinn
books.review: Laura Chinn has had the absolute saddest life. So much terrible parenting. So much loss. I enjoyed this memoir despite the hardships because Laura is relentlessly focused on healing.

books.title: Now I See You: A Memoir
books.author: Nicole C. Kear
books.review: I thought this would be more about the internal strength it requires to face a harrowing illness but it was more of a mommy blog post full of denial.

books.title: What My Bones Know
books.author: Stephanie Foo
books.review: Fantastic. Beautifully written. As someone who does not have CPTSD, but has a lot of self loathing and is hyper vigilant, I found this memoir to be so inspirational and real. --- I feel like ever since I got a smartphone, I am no longer capable of critical thinking and reflection. I am constantly consuming content but I never pause to reflect. Even when I read books, I rate them on Goodreads and then immediately move on. I started trying to write little blurbs about what I liked or disliked about the book recently and that has helped. But then I see these prolific writers on Goodreads who take the time to write essays on books they read and I think "HOW?" How do these people have so much insight to share? I am simply writing things like "I loved this book. Made me cry." or "I hated this book. Annoying narrator." Am I a child? Have I reverted? I used to have to write book reports and actually reflect on the material. I feel like even though I just read an amazing book, I don't even know if I have any articulate thoughts to say about it. I feel like I have been programmed to look for shortcuts. It's all about quantity and not about quality. I don't ponder or reflect. I consume and move on, consume and move on. But I don't absorb anything. "What My Bones Know" by Stephanie Foo is an incredible memoir. She grew up in San Jose to physically and verbally abusive parents who are ethnically Chinese but immigrated from Malaysia. Foo is adept at recognizing that "hurt people hurt people" and fights very hard to protect her parents and often rationalizes their behavior. It made me realize how fragile our sense of self can be and how susceptible children are to our parents' words and actions. I related to everything she said and then felt guilty because I had a loving and supportive childhood - so what is my excuse for being maladapted to society? Where did my hypervigilant inner monologue come from? It's clear to see where Foo's came from. She was constantly told that she was the source of her parents' pain and she internalized this belief as a concrete fact about her character. Another Goodreads account that I follow, Thomas, pointed out how impressive Foo's commitment to healing was, even when she felt like she wasn't making progress. She is incredibly introspective and reflective. She doesn't give up. She truly wants to do the work to better understand herself and change. I also grew up in the Bay Area, a place where there is definitely a lot of pressure on kids to achieve and perform well in school. I am from the East Bay, which has different culture dynamics than San Jose (aka it is way more white). I am also not a child of immigrant parents. Although a good chunk of my schools were made up of Asians, it was mostly white. I 100% fell for the stereotypical oversimplification of viewing (all) Asians as the model minority. I remember hearing that UCLA stood for "University of Caucasions Lost among Asians" and thinking it was funny. I went to Berkeley and felt like I was losing a competition constantly to Asians who "ruined the curve." This book gave me a layer of empathy that I was previously lacking. I was like her white high school teacher who just assumed that Asians were perfectionists that were stressed about getting a bad grade. I learned that is such a one dimensional way of looking at things. You truly have no idea what is going on in someone else's household and you can't understand the dynamics and motivations of others just by looking at them from the outside. It was heartbreaking when she went back to her old high school and connected with the school's social worker (a position that did not exist when she was in school). Hearing that some kids develop coke additions, not because they are spoiled kids that party too much, but so that they can stay awake for unhealthy periods of time working on school work or extracurricular activities. Truly heartbreaking. We are in the middle of a mental health crisis and our youth are taking the brunt of the attack. It made me want to become a mental health advocate for children (something I have looked into on a cursory level before - but CASA, Court Appointed Special Advocate, in San Diego rejected me because they didn't think I'd stay in San Diego long term, and they weren't wrong but I would have if I had been chosen! Anyway, I digress...) Foo did such an excellent job at weaving in scientific studies with her own personal thoughts and experiences. This book made me think about all the trauma that is passed down from person to person through our bodies. I have been meaning to read "The Body Keeps Score" for some time but have never gotten around to it. Before this book, I believed conceptually that physical trauma can be passed down generationally. But hearing the study about mice who reacted adversely to cherry blossoms even though they had never smelled them before and learning their parents were shocked when they smelled cherry blossoms really solidified my understanding. Parts made me feel despondent because there is so much pain and suffering in this world. How can we ever begin to heal? Foo had to work tirelessly for years before she saw any improvement. I love memoirs because I am always interested in "pulling back the curtain" and learning about raw experiences. She was open about using hostility in high school as a protective mechanism, an experience that I relate to today. I loved the parts of the audiobook where she included direct clips from her therapy sessions. Foo is a beautiful storyteller and truth teller. She made me feel seen and less alone. Her story is authentic, painful, and uplifting all at the same time. I highly recommend this book.

books.title: Stay True
books.author: Hua Hsu
books.review: Originally DNF 51% but decided to finish. Not worth it. Written by a pretentious Cal poli sci major...boring and not moving or profound at all.

books.title: Mother in the Dark
books.author: Kayla Maiuri
books.review: I despised this book.

books.title: My Body
books.author: Emily Ratajkowski
books.review: I hated her and thought she was part of the problem but now I feel like I know her and respect her more. I found this quote from an article about Taylor swift using the word "fat" in her music video that I think applies here as well: "So, is this backlash fair? And is it right for the finger to be pointed at one person who is a symptom of the problematic body image culture we've all found ourselves living in, rather than a conscious contributor to it?" It's not Emily's fault. She's a symptom of the system. I do agree with reviews that says she never reflects on what her impact is on women, only on how men have made her feel.

books.title: Detransition, Baby
books.author: Torrey Peters
books.review: Not sure how to feel. Made me think A LOT. I need to discuss with someone. "She knew that no matter how you self-identify ultimately, chances are that you succumb to becoming what the world treats you as."

books.title: The Way of Integrity: Finding the Path to Your True Self
books.author: Martha N. Beck
books.review: YES Martha! This book has so many golden nuggets in it. And it has so many techniques to practice IRL (something that I struggle with when I read self help books because I feel unsure how to apply things in my brain into my daily life). I listened to this on audiobook and I had just written an angry letter to someone I resent (with no plans to send it) and it made me feel 0% better. Then I listened to chapter 7 which asks you to do just that and then explains what a waste of time this is and you should be doing something creative instead - Oprah knows what's good.

books.title: I'm Glad My Mom Died
books.author: Jennette McCurdy
books.review: The parts where you can hear her crying. Gutted.

books.title: The Rabbit Hutch
books.author: Tess Gunty
books.review: Tense book. Intriguing. Depressing. Capitalism is ruining everything.

books.title: Happy-Go-Lucky
books.author: David Sedaris
books.review: I listened to David Sedaris' "Happy-Go-Lucky" on audiobook last night. Most of the time I find his essays delightful. This one made me laugh out loud a few times. I audibly gasped when he told a story about a man sticking a glass dildo up his rectum that exploded and my partner came running and asked what happened but I didn't hear him and kept maniacally cackling to myself. After finishing the collection and reading reviews for the book I realized he did do a lot of questionable things during the pandemic (as in he didn't follow any Covid rules), which was definitely a sign of his immense privilege. He also talked at length about how rich and successful he is now, which felt pretty unnecessary. He seemed pretty out of touch when he would go on and on about how much he missed shopping because that's all he and his sister, Amy, do together. I became weary when he discussed his sister, Tiffany's alleged abuse by their father. He essentially said Tiffany (who committed suicide) was an unreliable narrator and you couldn't trust what she said. But then he told various disturbing stories where his dad would take him alone to the bathroom and examine his asshole when David was a child, so this guy definitely seemed like a predator.

books.title: Group: How One Therapist and a Circle of Strangers Saved My Life
books.author: Christie Tate
books.review: I found her story interesting but was kind of depressed by how focused it was on finding a man instead of more about loving herself. Is her therapist a genius or a creep? There were a lot of moments where I couldn't tell. I could not deal with the lack of anonymity (it seemed so gossipy) but I guess we are only as sick as our secrets right?

books.title: All Together Now
books.author: Matthew Norman
books.review: I needed a beach read.

books.title: I'll Show Myself Out: Essays on Midlife and Motherhood
books.author: Jessi Klein
books.review: Sure she's privileged but she's also quite funny and I enjoy her essays.

books.title: Radically Content: Being Satisfied in an Endlessly Dissatisfied World
books.author: Jamie Varon
books.review: This is a magical book. It spoke to my soul. I have to take some time to reflect on all its wisdom.

books.title: Let's Take the Long Way Home: A Memoir of Friendship
books.author: Gail Caldwell
books.review: I wasn't sad when Caroline died (probably because I knew it was coming) but I SOBBED when clementine was attacked. Ugh. My heart. Beautiful story about deep female friendship.

books.title: There Are No Grown-ups: A Midlife Coming-of-Age Story
books.author: Pamela Druckerman
books.review: Delightful. Like a Gretchen Rubin book but more fun.

books.title: Disorientation
books.author: Elaine Hsieh Chou
books.review: Unsure of how to write a review of this book

books.title: Get Off Your "But": How to End Self-Sabotage and Stand Up for Yourself
books.author: Sean Stephenson
books.review: Loved this book. I was sad to learn that the author passed away in 2019. Some golden nuggets: "Stop blaming your boss, family, neighbor, lover, government, society, or God. You are the one at the scene of the crime every time something goes wrong in your life. Stop looking for a fall guy, a scapegoat, or an innocent bystander to pin your problems on. Until you take ownership for your life, you will always be chasing happiness." "Simply put, I love everyone so that no one can own me. If I hate another person, she owns me. It's true. Watch what happens in your life when you don't like someone: ‚Ä¢ He owns your very thoughts, every time you think about how awful he is. ‚Ä¢ He owns the conversations you have when you complain about him to your friends. ‚Ä¢ He even owns your behavior, when you change your plans to avoid him. ¬† When we hate someone, we become her little marionette. She can make us bob up and down, side to side, in any direction she chooses—that is, until we finally stop hating her and move on. Not being controlled by another person is not the only reason for loving everyone, but it is certainly a very important motivator." - I hold grudges for a long time even though I know the saying - Keeping resentments is like "swallowing poison and expecting the other person to die." I especially loved "Lesson 2: Watch What You Say to Yourself." - Lots to unpack here. I am very mean to myself and have a really hard time saying nice things to myself. "Fairness is an illusion. Fairness never existed and never will. No one in life gets less or more than anyone else. We just get different stuff. ¬† That's right. No one is dealt a bad or a good hand in life; we're just dealt cards. It's up to us to stay in the game and play. Sure, some cards look "better," but they're really not. If you look closely, you'll see that anything you feel has been taken from you—or never given to you at all—was replaced with other amazing opportunities and gifts. It's up to you to find them." - So much yes. I am constantly playing the "fairness police" and it is such a waste of time. From Lesson 5: Choose Your Friends Wisely: "Just as a goldfish swimming in a tank of diseased water inevitably becomes sick, a human hanging out in a toxic peer group eventually becomes toxic. When you place yourself in an environment, you eventually become the environment. It's inevitable." "It's up to you to apply the lessons and do the activities. If you just read this book passively, prepare for passive results." - Me with every self help book I've ever read...

books.title: Nowhere for Very Long
books.author: Brianna Madia
books.review: I like reading about unconventional paths. When I realized she was an influencer I became less intrigued. Not a deep book but an easy read that makes you want to quit your job and go live in a van in Utah (something I'm seriously considering...)

books.title: Animal
books.author: Lisa Taddeo
books.review: Disturbing but intriguing. Am I the only one who doesn't understand how she had two pregnancies/births in such quick succession??

books.title: Chemistry
books.author: Weike Wang
books.review: Delightful yet poignant.

books.title: Other People's Clothes
books.author: Calla Henkel
books.review: What a thrill!!! Couldn't put it down.

books.title: Happy for You
books.author: Claire Stanford
books.review: I loved this book. I rarely laugh out loud at books. This one also made me cry. So much to think about. Happiness is not something to be commodified and commercialized. Loved the quote about social media. "This is the reason that Montaigne argues for a separation between public and private spheres-the subjective nature of happiness demands it. We each need space to try to achieve happiness privately, without interference from the public. Montaigne would be horrified, for example, at the proliferation of social media, where we take what should, in his view, be private and make it public. Not only is it obscene, it doesn't serve us. We obscure our own happiness from ourselves by trying to project it and articulate it and prove it to others. These sites, he would say, flatten and falsify happiness when they ask us to affirm each other's life choices through likes."

books.title: No One Tells You This
books.author: Glynnis MacNicol
books.review: I actually really enjoyed this memoir even though at first I wasn't expecting to. I get mad when women obsess over the idea of marriage and babies. I was frustrated when a similar memoir "what I was doing while you were breeding" ended with her getting married and having a baby after she bashed the idea relentlessly. But I have realized that it's not the fault of the women who write these memoirs, it's the tropes of society and how we force women into thinking success = marriage + baby. Do I know what trope means? At first I was annoyed when she wanted a gold star for paying her own bills and buying her own groceries - like yeah that's not a feminist achievement. But I do see how it would be draining to not have an emergency contact to rely on. I just hate how single women are pitied but no one bats an eye at single men. She discussed the plight of her mother quite delicately. It was devastating to see the way Parkinson's robs people of not dying alone. Made me sad when she said something to the effect of the only women to look up to were Laura ingles wilder and Carrie Bradshaw..? To me, Carrie Bradshaw embodies every toxic female stereotype ever. I deeply loathe her. "As I continued to worry over what sort of future I was setting myself up for, she seemed a painful cautionary tale that life was not a savings plan, accrued now for enjoyment later. I was alive now. My responsibility was to live now as fully as possible."

books.title: The People We Keep
books.author: Allison Larkin
books.review: Lots of issues with this book. Felt like reading "Wild" by Cheryl Strayed. Everyone wants to have sex with her and help her. She feels alone and like she can't be loved. Blah blah blah.

books.title: Tell Me How to Be
books.author: Neel Patel
books.review: Normally I hate when the narrator switches back and forth but I loved this book and both characters.

books.title: Girl in Pieces
books.author: Kathleen Glasgow
books.review: Devoured in a day. Heartbreaking.

books.title: Better Than Before: Mastering the Habits of Our Everyday Lives
books.author: Gretchen Rubin
books.review: I listened to this on a flight and definitely nodded off during some of it but I am very into habit formation so I liked it. I'm also the same personality (classic upholder) as Gretchen so I don't find her as jarring as others do.

books.title: Rock Paper Scissors
books.author: Alice Feeney
books.review: Meh. Struggled to finish. Found it pretty boring - not thrilling at all. The twist was mildly compelling but not enough to make this book enjoyable.

books.title: Healthy as F*ck: The Habits You Need to Get Lean, Stay Healthy, and Kick Ass at Life
books.author: Oonagh Duncan
books.review: I am very much an "all or nothing" person so I liked the part about being okay with half assing things instead of beating yourself up about not being perfect. But I didn't love this book as much as all the other reviewers.

books.title: Severance
books.author: Ling Ma
books.review: Station 11 meets crying in h mart. I was on the edge of my seat. But then it just...ended. I guess that's fine.

books.title: Me Talk Pretty One Day
books.author: David Sedaris
books.review: Loved the first half but the second half was pretty boring.

books.title: Crying in H Mart
books.author: Michelle Zauner
books.review: Like others said - it feels wrong to give this book a rating. I feel obligated to give this 4 stars even though I want to give it 3. Devoured the first half. But after her mother's death I felt like the book faltered and it was all about food and I started skimming. I never do that so that was disappointing. My parents moved to Eugene so I liked all the parts about Oregon. Made me think about my difficult relationship with my mother...she is definitely not a "mommy mom"

books.title: Inside Out
books.author: Demi Moore
books.review: Not really sure why I read this book but I thought it was alright.

books.title: The Happiness Project
books.author: Gretchen Rubin
books.review: I get why people say her perspective is a very narrow one filled with privilege but I really like the idea of dedicating each month to an area of your life that you'd like to improve. I love how she didn't do an "eat, pray, love" and quit her job and do yoga in Bali - you can focus on happiness in your day to day life.

books.title: Malibu Rising
books.author: Taylor Jenkins Reid
books.review: Did not enjoy. Cheesy. Is this her thing - writing about "celebrity-like" characters from the past? I liked daisy jones & the six but won't read another one of hers.

books.title: Nonviolent Communication: A Language of Life
books.author: Marshall B. Rosenberg

books.title: Thanks for Waiting: The Joy (& Weirdness) of Being a Late Bloomer
books.author: Doree Shafrir
books.review: Almost exactly the same as "You'll Grow Out Of It" Liked the first half. The second half was ALL about her IVF journey and it just wasn't that interesting. Then the book just kind of ended.

books.title: Three Women
books.author: Lisa Taddeo
books.review: Justice for Maggie. Very triggering. Believe women. There was a teacher at my middle school who was beloved just like this teacher until it was discovered that he had sexual relations with 8th grade girls but he did not get away with it and I believe is now (still?) serving time. But I know that's not how most stories play out. This is not a book about female desire. It's a book about how little the world values women and thus how little women value themselves. Made me very sad. Related to a lot of it.

books.title: Bowing to Light: A Mother's Journey Through Grief
books.author: Rachael Maier
books.review: Heartbreakingly beautiful. She writes with the same ethereal lightness that she radiates in person. I read "The Light Between Us" by Laura Lynn Jackson just before this. It's all about how we are connected to those that cross - specifically to children we lose. I am now a firm believer that we carry those we have lost with us always. I felt deeply touched by Elora's rainbow signs for her mother. "Despair means you have reached the bottom, yes, but it also means you will be starting upward next. Where there's a going down, there's always a coming up."

books.title: The Light Between Us: Stories from Heaven, Lessons for the Living
books.author: Laura Lynne Jackson
books.review: Loved it.

books.title: Make Time: How to Focus on What Matters Every Day
books.author: Jake Knapp
books.review: Lots of good tips

books.title: A Good Neighborhood
books.author: Therese Anne Fowler
books.review: This book is making me depressed when the tree is dying because I've never thought about how cutting down a tree disrupts the natural ecosystem of the area. Wow what a depressing book. It was so slow and I kept waiting for it to get better and it never did. Bad writing.

books.title: Based on a True Story
books.author: Delphine de Vigan
books.review: Kind of reminded me of "sharp objects" (which I only watched - did not read)

books.title: Beautiful World, Where Are You
books.author: Sally Rooney
books.review: Did not enjoy.

books.title: Uncanny Valley
books.author: Anna Wiener
books.review: Really enjoyed the first half (presumably about her time at mixpanel). Felt like the second half (about GitHub) dragged a bit. The ending was depressing. Excellent writing.

books.title: Cutting for Stone
books.author: Abraham Verghese
books.review: Tough read. I had to put it down a few times. But I found it pretty engrossing near the end. Sad. Beautiful story telling. Inspiring that this author was just like I am going to Iowa to get my MFA after being a doctor. I am rethinking my career and I like seeing that you can always reinvent yourself. Oh forgot to say I HATE GENET. HATE.

books.title: Marry Him: The Case for Settling for Mr. Good Enough
books.author: Lori Gottlieb
books.review: Mixed feelings about this one. I do think it's important to focus on what makes someone a good long term partner instead of solely looking for a "spark." She is so absurdly picky it made me slightly dislike her and I really liked "maybe you should talk to someone." I liked her Ted talk about changing your story. Ultimately instead of focusing on people's flaws you should focus on their positive attributes - this is something I struggle with.

books.title: What I Was Doing While You Were Breeding
books.author: Kristin Newman
books.review: Am I the only one that finds it grating that in the end she has a baby via IVF??? With that title??

books.title: Shrill: Notes from a Loud Woman
books.author: Lindy West
books.review: Was not expecting to love this. Made me think about the fat-phobia that I have and made me want to be better. But the best was her story about rape jokes. It really struck me. I wish more men would read this but I know they won't. But she is making the world better. And I'm so sad that she deals with so many trolls every day.

books.title: Transcendent Kingdom
books.author: Yaa Gyasi
books.review: Too slow. Couldn't get into it. Decided to finish. Don't get what all the fuss is about. Very boring book. Nothing happens.

books.title: Yearbook
books.author: Seth Rogen
books.review: Amusing

books.title: I Feel Bad About My Neck and Other Thoughts on Being a Woman
books.author: Nora Ephron
books.review: It's a no from me dawg

books.title: Heartburn
books.author: Nora Ephron
books.review: No depth but I had fun for a day.

books.title: Buy Yourself the F*cking Lilies: And Other Rituals to Fix Your Life, from Someone Who's Been There
books.author: Tara Schuster
books.review: Now that I've read "what my bones know," I feel like this author probably has a milder version of c-ptsd

books.title: You Are a Badass: How to Stop Doubting Your Greatness and Start Living an Awesome Life
books.author: Jen Sincero
books.review: I guess I'm in the minority but I really liked this book! Lots of good advice.

books.title: From Heartbreak to Wholeness: The Hero's Journey to Joy
books.author: Kristine Carlson

books.title: Mating in Captivity: Reconciling the Erotic and the Domestic
books.author: Esther Perel

books.title: Fleishman Is in Trouble
books.author: Taffy Brodesser-Akner
books.review: Loved it. Made me sad.

books.title: Breath: The New Science of a Lost Art
books.author: James Nestor

books.title: Sober Curious: The Blissful Sleep, Greater Focus, Limitless Presence, and Deep Connection Awaiting Us All on the Other Side of Alcohol
books.author: Ruby Warrington

books.title: Quit Like a Woman: The Radical Choice to Not Drink in a Culture Obsessed with Alcohol
books.author: Holly Whitaker
books.review: Picked this book because Chrissy teigen said it inspired her. The first part was super thought provoking. I truly do agree that one day we will look back at alcohol the way we look at smoking and say "we didn't know any better." I really enjoyed the focus on self esteem and liking yourself instead of depriving yourself.

books.title: Behold the Dreamers
books.author: Imbolo Mbue
books.review: Did not think it would end the way it did but I guess that's a good thing.

books.title: Dear Girls: Intimate Tales, Untold Secrets, & Advice for Living Your Best Life
books.author: Ali Wong
books.review: Such a riot.

books.title: Option B: Facing Adversity, Building Resilience, and Finding Joy
books.author: Sheryl Sandberg

books.title: Commonwealth
books.author: Ann Patchett
books.review: Meh. Hard to keep track of all the characters given all the children and all the divorces...

books.title: The Stationery Shop
books.author: Marjan Kamali
books.review: Long. Boring. Do not get what the fuss is about.

books.title: The Vanishing Half
books.author: Brit Bennett
books.review: Depressing.

books.title: Anxious People
books.author: Fredrik Backman
books.review: What a deplorable book. I detested every bit of it. The story was preposterous. Seemingly written by a dim witted middle schooler. I hated every character. Couldn't wait for it to end. What on earth are these glowing reviews about? Did we read the same book?

books.title: American Dirt
books.author: Jeanine Cummins
books.review: Enthralling

books.title: Maybe You Should Talk to Someone: A Therapist, Her Therapist, and Our Lives Revealed
books.author: Lori Gottlieb
books.review: I want to be a therapist but I am intimidated by the price tag and time commitment that grad school demands. Also, whenever I share this interest with actual therapists, they immediately tell me not to pursue this path. Why? I started re-reading Lori Gottlieb's books, "Maybe You Should Talk to Someone" and "Marry Him: The Case for Settling for Mr. Good Enough" (we'll save an analysis of that second title for another post) because I remember that she had a very circuitous path to becoming a therapist. She began her career working in television in Los Angeles, then decided to go to medical school at age 28. She glosses over how she went from being a language major in college to Stanford medical school (where she completed her undergrad), but I understand that her career journey is not the focus of her books. At 33, she decides to drop out of med school to focus on journalism. Per Wikipedia, she was born in 1966 and obtained a Masters of Clinical Psychology at Pepperdine University in 2010. This means she was 44 when she finished her masters! This gives me immense hope. Although I reread this book hoping to learn more about her career, I was reminded of how much I love this book and what a great writer she is. Cried throughout the Julie and John stories. I love therapy!!!

books.title: Home Fire
books.author: Kamila Shamsie
books.review: Devastating

books.title: Ask Again, Yes
books.author: Mary Beth Keane
books.review: I was intrigued the whole time.

books.title: The Cost of Living: A Working Autobiography
books.author: Deborah Levy
books.review: Very boring. And whiny. I also hated that she kept calling her friend "the man that cried at the funeral" - was that supposed to be clever? Why did the NYT think this book was notable in 2018? It was a total slog, even though it was so short.

books.title: The Dutch House
books.author: Ann Patchett
books.review: Engrossing.

books.title: Let's Explore Diabetes with Owls: Essays, Etc.
books.author: David Sedaris
books.review: Not nearly as good as calypso. I listened to parts of it as an audiobook and they had Andrew bird do interludes between each story which I absolutely DETESTED. And I love Andrew bird. Would not recommend this one.

books.title: Calypso
books.author: David Sedaris
books.review: Delightful

books.title: The Education of an Idealist: A Memoir
books.author: Samantha Power
books.review: Loved the beginning about her upbringing but found the bulk of the book seemed to be a collection of stories saying "look at all the noble things I did." Wayyyy wayyyy too long. Couldn't wait to be done. Sad because I wanted to love this book.

books.title: The Lager Queen of Minnesota
books.author: J. Ryan Stradal
books.review: In the end it was a little too hokey for me but I enjoyed the characters and it was an easy, quick, fun read.

books.title: A Visit from the Goon Squad
books.author: Jennifer Egan

books.title: The Artist's Way: A Spiritual Path to Higher Creativity
books.author: Julia Cameron
books.review: Changed my life.

books.title: Daisy Jones & The Six
books.author: Taylor Jenkins Reid
books.review: I'm embarrassed to admit I didn't know this was fiction. I googled the photo of daisy in the pool and found out this was in fact not a true story and I was sad! at first I thought I would hate the format but it totally worked and I loved it. All the females are so great. So many good quotes. Disappointed that they aren't real but I guess that means the book accomplished something raw and I like that. Fun read. If you need me I'll be listening to rumors.

books.title: The Idiot
books.author: Elif Batuman
books.review: Started off promising but turned into a slog. Painful to read. Then it just ends and you regret all the hard work you put in to read this dull book.

books.title: Normal People
books.author: Sally Rooney
books.review: Wanted to read to see if it was different from the show but it was so boring because the show an exact replica of the book. Nothing new. The show is aesthetically pleasing but the two characters are buffoons. I liked conversations with friends but this book lacks the smart dialog - it's just self absorbed children failing to communicate. Would not recommend. I also hate how spineless Marianne is - cringey.

books.title: Single State of Mind
books.author: Andi Dorfman
books.review: Total drivel but I needed to escape for a minute.

books.title: Love Warrior
books.author: Glennon Doyle Melton
books.review: What a crock of shit. Why do I keep doing this to myself? I felt the same way about untamed. I related to the beginning. But then I realized she refuses to take any accountability for her life. She gets sooo preachy in the second half and it makes me want to throw things. Skip all Glennon Doyle books. Only read brene brown if you want to read about true vulnerability.

books.title: Conversations with Friends
books.author: Sally Rooney
books.review: Devoured it in a day. How is she only 29? Love her writing. Agree that characters were unlikeable but that didn't stop me from enjoying the book.

books.title: Untamed
books.author: Glennon Doyle
books.review: Could not wait for this book to end! Audiobook was painful. So preachy but I don't aspire to be anything like this woman who claims to be an inspirational speaker. Save your time and listen to someone who is less self involved and self obsessed.
